151414780.review:
Mirror's Edge is an absolute gem that stands out in the gaming landscape, offering a unique and exhilarating experience that is both visually stunning and mentally engaging. Ditching the conventional first-person shooter formula, Mirror's Edge takes players on a breathtaking parkour journey through a beautifully designed cityscape.

One of the game's standout features is its striking minimalist art style. The clean, vibrant aesthetics create a visually appealing world that is both futuristic and immersive. The color palette is carefully chosen, making each environment pop with a sense of life and energy. It's a refreshing departure from the dark and gritty tones often found in other games, and it adds a sense of optimism to the overall experience.

The parkour mechanics in Mirror's Edge are nothing short of brilliant. The game's protagonist, Faith, moves with unparalleled grace and agility, allowing players to seamlessly navigate the urban landscape. The fluidity of movement is not only a joy to control but also a testament to the developers' commitment to delivering a unique and satisfying gameplay experience.

The level design deserves special mention. Each level is a meticulously crafted puzzle that challenges players to think on their feet and plan their movements strategically. The game encourages creativity in finding the best routes, rewarding players for mastering the art of traversal. The rooftop chases and daring leaps between buildings are heart-pounding moments that keep you on the edge of your seat.

Mirror's Edge also boasts an atmospheric soundtrack that complements the game's pace and tone perfectly. The music intensifies during high-stakes moments, adding to the overall sense of urgency and excitement. The combination of visuals, gameplay, and music creates a holistic experience that draws players into its world and keeps them hooked from start to finish.

In addition to its stellar single-player campaign, Mirror's Edge offers a unique time trial mode that lets players compete for the fastest completion times on each level. This adds a layer of replayability, as mastering the intricacies of the parkour mechanics becomes a rewarding pursuit.

Mirror's Edge is more than just a game; it's a bold and innovative experiment that successfully breaks away from gaming conventions. It's a testament to the idea that games can be both visually striking and intellectually stimulating. If you're looking for a gaming experience that challenges your skills, captivates your senses, and leaves you wanting more, Mirror's Edge is an absolute must-play.

151079510.review:
Mirror's Edge is on of only very few games to have such a big legacy and public recognition for how relativly small and unlike anything els it is. 

With the past years of EA, dice and the gaming landscape as a whole in mind, Mirror's Edge feels like a strange dream. A once-in-a-lifetime coming together of the best that Dice can offer and the guts of EA to publiche something closer to art then your more run-of-the-mill action shooting whatevers, especialy in the golden age of franchises like CoD, Halo and GTA4.

I've had this game close to heart from the very first time I got my hands on it, back in 2008. It's art, movement and world have left such a unique and extremly memorable mark on me and part of gameing as a whole, it's easy to see why it's still in the zeitgeist for so meny life long fans.

While Mirror's Edge catalyst was alright, perhaps even quite good, it's predassesor has that extra bit of personality, character and pure vision that later games and potential spiritual successors just cannot recreate. It's specific team, the year of in wich it was made and the willingness of the AAA market and the gamers both to try something wholy new will most likely never come again.

There are fools who say games cannot be art. To them I say meny things. Undertale, Assassin's Creed 2, Journey, Deus Ex Human Revolutions, The Witcher 3 and... Mirror's Edge.

Now I hear this game will be removed forever by the powers that be, damn them to hell, and so I'm here to tell you this: Please, buy this game and play it. Experience what me and many like me experienced all the way back in 2008 and play Dice's best game ever. Dice's best ever piece of absolute Art.

Well worth a try on a sale - you may just find your new favorite game.

150184777.review: 14 years after release and this remains one of my favorite games of all time. As a fan of movement based games this is the one that started it all. The campaign is rather short (4-6 hours) but infinitely replayable as I've beaten it dozens of times now trying to go faster or try different routes. The gunplay sucks but the emphasis is meant to be on running rather than fighting anyway. The story is also pretty forgettable but this is made up for by the stellar art direction and soundtrack which breathe so much life into the atmosphere of this game. There isn't really another game out there like this one, highly recommended if you enjoy movement/momentum games or just want a short and relatively easy to pick up action game.

150074418.review: I like parkour in first person games but the mechanics here are far from anything I'd call intuitive or polished. The level design is extremely basic, forcing players to go down the same paths the developers force you down. Normally that wouldn't necessarily be an issue for a singleplayer experience but for a parkour game its almost antithetical at best and like a QTE simulator at it's worst. The shooting is just boring too whenever they force you into those sections, which is ironic considering this is from the same developers who made Battlefield. The only two positives I can reasonably give this game is that it ends quickly and the art direction is pretty great, still looks really good to this day in spite of the outdated graphics. Just save yourself 27 dollars and look at the pictures of this game, I bought it for 3 and I still feel like I got punked.

149273164.review:
Surprisingly good gunplay. We all already know that this game is famous for it's Parkour, but something I didn't expect at all was that a) you can pick up the guns of your enemies and b) using those guns is so fucking fun and unique.

What I think makes it work, at least for me personally, is that for 1, guns have a relatively small amount of ammo, for 2, bullets do a somewhat realistic amount of damage, and for 3, in this game you cannot reload said ammo.

It's not like most FPSs where you pick up a handgun and have like 50 shots to work with till you need to reload but each shot does peanuts of damage so it's a battle of stamina, spamming the trigger, and timing the reloads whilst dodging. Nah here a gun kills an enemy in like 2 shots, but each gun only has like 6 bullets, and since you can't reload once a gun is out it's permanently useless and you gotta find a new one, so it becomes it's own gun of resource management, using your shots wisely, and learning when to just a drop a gun even if it isn't empty. Such fun stuff and is honestly the main thing that gets me coming back to the game

149131843.review: I don't think this game holds up as much as it used to. 149125931.review:
Average combat experience is to run at a moderate pace in a straight line with no cover at a guy actively shooting at you.  Of the 16 shots he fires he will connect exactly 0.   Then left click 2 times and he's been killed instantly.  Now you can take his gun that does about 1/4 of the damage per shot that a light punch does and fire 5 times at his 1 (one) ally and automatically throw the gun on the ground for some reason. 

The game sets up an illusion of a sprawling cityscape that you have to traverse and find your way around when the reality is that there is really only ever one, extremely linear, correct path.

Your top speed is like a brisk walk.  Jumping feels sluggish.  The automatic ledge grab fails about 60% of the time.  As long as you press lctrl before you land long falls do no damage, unless it's 1 inch beyond some arbitrary barrier in which case you die horribly and get to listen to some weird hearing-damaging sound effect.

Blows my mind that this game has a single positive review.  Praise Christ.

149098562.review:
I've had this game on various platforms over the years, after getting it back in 2009. I felt inspired to learn Parkour when I first played it, and it's a decision that I never regretted. Learning Parkour reshaped the way that I look at the world and eventually even changed how I approached things in my day to day life. This game is special to me, and there really isn't anything else quite like it.

Faith controls like how you would expect a person to feel, if you were controlling them with a M/KB. There's a distinct feeling of weight to controlling Faith and it's not anything that another game has managed to pull off, much less in first person. Faith feels fantastic to control though, and through learning her move set you can really get around the city with ease. And boy does it feel great to be able to easily pass obstacles that would otherwise stop a normal person. The combat in this game isn't always viewed very fondly and I honestly think that's fair despite enjoying it myself. The tutorial doesn't do the best job at teaching you how to fight and disarm opponents but just remember to watch out for when weapons flash red. That's the time to disarm. You can press left or right and space to sidestep too, you can use that to dodge.

The music is just great, Solar Fields did a great job on this sound track and the main theme Still Alive is a fantastic song. I've listened to the OST plenty of times over the years and I can't see my love for it fading away.

It's a bit hard for me to say that the story is good in a traditional sense. It's well written and there's plenty to work through, but the game itself doesn't directly go into it very much. I feel like they really missed out on fleshing out the game with the story that was there, but the game itself is relatively short and can be completed in about 4-6 depending on how you do. There was plenty more that they could have gone with, but at least the game stays strong all the way through. I don't feel like the game has any real weak points. Save for the combat, but I still enjoy the combat personally.

The art direction for this game is fantastic too. It's a very pretty game, even after all these years I think screenshots from this game would make fantastic wallpapers. The minimal color pallet is a beautiful and wise design choice. It's a very distinct style, but it also does an excellent job at guiding the player without using idiot arrows at every turn to tell you where to go.

147973370.review:
Un juego único para la época debido a la gran calidad y originalidad tanto de su historia como de sus mecánicas y aspecto gráfico. Un juego para repetir en más de una ocasión, pero que no deja de ser demasiado caro para la poca durabilidad del juego, pues en apenas unas 3 horas puedes terminar la historia completa. A parte de eso, puedes llevar a cabo carreras establecidas o carreras contrarreloj, nada más.

Aunque es un proyecto increíble a pesar de su brevedad (que debo recalcar que me gusta más el posterior, Mirror's Edge: Catalyst), es cierto que pueden sacarse algunos defectos de este juego, que si tienen cierto peso para el mismo. En algunas zonas, podrás verte entorpecido por unas mecánicas que a veces no terminan siendo del todo eficientes. Si bien los movimientos de Faith son mucho más realistas que en Catalyst, morirás en diversas ocasiones por la ineficiencia de las mecánicas y movimientos. El peor de todos (ATENCIÓN SPOILER) ocurre cuando Jacknife falla en su salto mientras huye de Faith, cayendo inconsciente al suelo. Para alcanzarle, deberás avanzar a tu izquierda sobre unas tuberías. Cuando estés en la segunda, no podrás agarrarte a la tercera por mucho que la alcances sobradamente; Faith, por alguna razón, no se agarra y cae. Para subirte, te ves en la obligación de subir hasta arriba del todo en la segunda tubería para saltar a la siguiente, a veces ni te agarras y llegas directamente al otro ventilador. Este error ocurre debido a que, según las mecánicas del juego, Faith está establecida para poder agarrarse a tuberías consiguientes, pero la tercera en esta zona está un poco más alejada de lo que debería, por lo que se desentiende de ella.

Otro defecto que podría sacar trataría de los enemigos, en concreto de los soldados armados (o cuerpos de policía de PK). Estos muchas veces resultan demasiado poderosos y difíciles de vencer, a veces aunque utilices el botón de ralentizar el tiempo. En algunas ocasiones, morirás independientemente de lo que hagas, pues pueden llegar a matarte antes de que incluso te acerques a ellos, pues además nunca están solos. Por ello, la dificultad en normal ya parece estar un poco más elevada. De la difícil, ni hablamos.

En resumen, ¿recomiendo el juego? Sin duda. Sin embargo, es mucho más recomendable comprarlo en físico (que cuesta menos de la mitad) o en otras páginas donde estén más baratos (donde puedan probar su fiabilidad al 100%, claro). 20€ me parece demasiado por este juego, solamente por la poca duración del mismo.

147657663.review:
For the time it came out it's quite revolutionary with the super in-depth parkour mechanics. But as for the game itself, I honestly can't say I had too much fun with it. 

The parkour mechanics were very convoluted imo. On one hand, there are several different ways you can reach an objective for most roof sections which made me really feel like I was actually Faith and was a professional parkourist who had to figure stuff out as they went. On the other hand, the parkour mechanics can be super finicky and end up confusing actions for one another (eg wallrunning vs 180 degree walljumping vs 90 degree wall jumping vs grabbing a ledge). Plus there were lots of parkour sections that were really confusing for no particular reason and honestly should've been pretty straightforward considering once I figured them out I could freerun them easily.

Combat encounters are unclear on whether you should run or fight, making parts where there was only one forced option nearly impossible to tell in some cases. There are a variety of different weapons that enemies will carry, each with their own unique stats, but for the most part you're punished every step of the way for taking on enemies. There's a gameplay hint that suggests isolating a single enemy so you aren't overwhelmed, but how exactly am I meant to do that when they all take the same path to get to me? There's a very unique parry-like mechanic where you can grab their weapon during a shove attack and one-shot them while also taking their weapon which is cool, but it's super inconsistent even with the added benefit of the slow-mo ability designed specifically to better pull off parries.

The story was messy, had zero stakes for me to be invested in, and the ending was terrible. I persevered hoping there would be some new parkour mechanics introduced or some new combat mechanics, but past maybe the 2nd or 3rd level and beyond a unique enemy that can both keep up with the player and is adept in melee combat I'd pretty much seen everything. Maybe Catalyst polishes the rough edges of Mirror's Edge (no pun intended), but honestly Mirror's Edge hasn't aged well at all and seems super overrated.

147381653.review:
Mirror's Edge™ se destaca en un mar de juegos por su enfoque innovador en la jugabilidad y el diseño visual. La decisión de centrarse en el parkour y el movimiento fluido en primera persona crea una experiencia inmersiva y emocionante que se siente fresca y emocionante desde el primer momento.

El diseño del mundo es una obra de arte por sí misma. La ciudad distópica en la que se desarrolla el juego es un laberinto de rascacielos y edificios brillantes, creando un paisaje urbano que es tanto hermoso como desafiante. Los colores vibrantes y el estilo minimalista hacen que el juego sea visualmente impresionante y memorable.

La mecánica del parkour se ejecuta con precisión y fluidez. Los movimientos, desde saltos y deslizamientos hasta escaladas y carreras en la pared, están diseñados de manera realista y se sienten naturales para el personaje principal, Faith. Esto crea una sensación de autenticidad y control total sobre los movimientos del personaje.

La narrativa del juego es intrigante y está llena de giros sorprendentes. A través de la perspectiva de Faith, los jugadores se sumergen en una historia de intriga, conspiración y lucha por la libertad. La conexión emocional con el personaje principal y su lucha por la justicia y la verdad añaden profundidad a la experiencia.

La música y los efectos de sonido son sobresalientes. La banda sonora electrónica complementa perfectamente la energía y la emoción del juego, mientras que los efectos de sonido inmersivos, como el sonido del viento mientras te deslizas por los tejados o los pasos resonantes en los pasillos, aumentan la sensación de estar realmente en el mundo del juego.

My biggest issue is no native FOV slider and the workaround being a keybind that you have to press at the start of every new chapter, which when you do also brings up issues such as the skybox tearing in certain areas of levels (notably the first "boss" fight where you have to parry the big security guard), scopes not actually zooming in on snipers (which has to be mitigated by having a keybind to set your FOV to 0, I didn't do this because it was too much work and dealt with basically a sniper with a digital iron sight), and some in-game cut-scenes having clipping issues. This is all, however, a very modern complaint and I do understand that 2009 on Xbox was a very different time and despite the rough spots it's definitely worth a playthrough, but pick it up on sale.

146339709.review:
Mirror's Edge is probably one of my favourite games. Where to begin? 

Firstly, this game looks beautiful for a 2008 game, absolutely amazing art style that makes every colour and clean edge pop out. In so many video games a thing I love to do is break the game by jumping on things you should not, and generally exploring. If you have played Portal/Portal 2, some highlights of those games were not the puzzles, but when you had to find various ways to escape. Now put that gameplay into a whole expansive game and you have Mirror's Edge.

A feeling of sadness however, is also present. This game was made by EA, but not the one today. Such an imaginative corporation turned into something from the in game city itself. Out of the trend of remaking popular genres into beloved indie games, I believe Mirror's Edge deserves it the most. The music, the gameplay and art really make this game special and sadly not talked about. I don't feel angry at EA though, just sad... I think these feelings can be perfectly summarised in the amazing song from the game "Still Alive" -

I have changed, I have changed
Just like you, just like you
For how long, for how long must I wait?
I know there's something wrong
Your concrete heart isn't beating
And I've tried to make it come alive
No shadows, just red lights
Now I'm here to rescue you

I'm still alive, I'm still alive.

I didn't get a chance to play it when it came out, so I gave it a go in 2023, and it still looks beautiful. The unique art direction aged well and looks gorgeous even after almost 15 years if combined with 4k and AutoHDR. Only subtitles don't look well in 4k. Sadly, I couldn't play at 120 Hz as it resulted in too much screen tearing, and GSync didn't help.

The gameplay is remarkable and includes a lot of jumping and occasional fighting and shooting. The story is simple but unimportant in this kind of game.

The game is relatively short and can be finished in 7 hours if you focus only on the main campaign. Additionally, you can try to beat your best time in missions or collect hidden suitcases.

If you use a game controller, to some, using LB for jumping might seem annoying and require some time to learn, but it makes sense because you need to be able to jump and move the camera simultaneously, so be patient!

145539049.review:
"Once the city used to pulse with energy. Dirty and dangerous, but alive and wonderful. Now it's something else."

[i]Mirror's Edge[/i] is an action-adventure platform game developed by DICE and published by Electronic Arts.

[b]Story[/b]
Mirror's Edge is set in a near-future city where comfortable life and non-existent crime are achieved thanks to regime that controls the media and its citizens. Here there is also an underground crew of parkour couriers called Runners, who deliver private goods and sensitive information across the city to those who oppose the goverment, marking them as a threat.
You play as one of the Runners named Faith Connors, who after one of the runs finds out about her sister being framed for murder. She sets out to discover secrets hiding behind the assassination and to prove sisters innocence.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Pretty simple deal, utilize Faith's parkour skills to navigate the city and complete levels in order to progress! Jump between rooftops, wallrun, slide down, vault over obstacles, climb and more to make your way through cities infrastructure.
Key part in successful parkour lies within momentum, as taking a moment to gather speed will let you run faster, jump farther or climb higher.
Game also features help in navigation called Runner Vision, which highlights certain objects or paths with red colour to help you find a way forward, plus to make gameplay feel smoother as you won't waste time and speed in searching where you have to go.

Of course Faith doesn't have that easy, and will have to deal with police force on her path. Game allows you to outsmart opponents and utilize parkour skills to simply pass them, but when moment comes where you are face to face with enemy, you have to get handy. You can perform melee attacks, block and counter incoming strikes, but considering most enemies doesn't want to get close and personal, you might have to reach out and disarm them.
Faith can use all firearms to kill enemies without the need to get her hands messy, yet bigger weapons than pistol not only slow her down but also prevent from performing parkour moves, forcing you to go guns blazing. Which makes sense, I haven't seen anyone yet do parkour with heavy machine gun in both hands.
So game gives you certain freedom in approach: parkour to evade, slap everyone you see or grab cold iron and use it against enemies.
Getting hit results in health loss and screen being more red than usual, with medicine for such issue being few second of no-damage-taken period when regeneration kicks in. Classic. Get too much damage and you will revisit recent checkpoint. Same applies to parkour, as screwup in a roof jump results in death...and that crunchy sound once Faith lands, or rather splatters...ughhhh, hate it.

Each level has 3 hidden yellow bags serving as collectibles, though you get nothing from collecting them, beside sense of self-acomplishment I suppose. Look for Runner's marks and search areas close to them!

[b]Playtime, replayability and other modes[/b]
It took me less than 5 hours to make through the story.
Definitely a game that has to be played twice as your first playthrough while still being enjoyable, will feature a learning curve on how to tackle levels and deal with parkour mechanics, making it feel rather rough. Second playthrough thanks to gathered experience and few hours under the belt should be simply more satisfying, seamless from gameplay perspective. Plus, you can collect useless collectible bags you might have missed out on!

Additionally you have a time trial mode with two options, both rely on parkouring your way as fast as possible and earning medals based on your time. One copies missions from the story, and second focuses on shorter sections with checkpoints you have to pass. If you love cutting miliseconds from a clock and finding most optimal way to the finish line then these modes are made for you!

[b]Pros and cons[/b]
Fantastic controls and fluid movement that make up for parkour with the addition of momentum mechanic, create immersive experience. It's pleasant, responsive and offers solid curve for those who might want to advance their skills in the game by spending more time with it to learn all the little tricks and nuances.
One cannot mention Mirror's Edge without talking about fantastic visual side it offers. Mix of sticking out white colour with primary colours used in the game, bounded by ton of soft shadows gives game a very unique artstyle that looks great even today.

As for 'mixed' element I throw in whole story, not only because presentation through animated cutscenes looks average at best but also due to few confusing plot moments. Very okay, nothing special type.

Levels themselfs also can fit into mixed category, due to them being on every side of the spectrum. While I understand game is linear, sometimes it's so restricted and on rails it just doesn't provide freedom parkour is known for. Additionally there are few moments, due to combat sections for example, where Mirror's Edge becomes a trial and error game which can lead to frustration. But there are chapters which not only feature multiple roads to avoid enemies, giving you freedom to get bit creative, they have solid variety of obstacles to create really fun parkour moments.

For negatives, combat. Not enjoyable, ruins the flow, quite ofter feeling unnecessary for the sake of padding the time and guns you can utilize are horrible from gunplay perspective. Melee is not that bad but sadly game has very few melee encounters and that is where problem lies, it focuses too much on picking up the gun and enganging in shootouts that break the pacing, rather than on swift hand-to-hand brawling.

Ultimately Mirror's Edge is all about flow. If you will quickly get into a game, get a feel of mechanics and movement, it will be a fantastic, smooth sailing experience. However if you get into that one section which makes you fail twice or thrice, you lose focus or get annoyed, or you just don't get into a game as much as you thought, it can feel like a slog, where you are not progressing naturally and have to fight tooth and nail for every checkpoint, making game not as enjoyable as some (myself included) claim. I thought opening cinematic mentioning whole "Parkour flow" deal was over exaggerating but after a playthrough I do have to take it back and fully agree.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Fantastic visual style and well crafted parkour make Mirror's Edge a unique title definitely worth playing, even if unsatisfying combat and few "Trial and Error" moments might ruin your flow.

Feel free to check out [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31947302/] my curator page [/url] for more reviews!

145168999.review:
Buen juego, completado en 6,8 horas.

Recuerdo la primera vez que jugué a [i]Mirror's Edge[/i] cuando salió allá por 2009, las mecánicas del parkour me resultaron muy novedosas ya que nunca había visto un juego que las empleara en primera persona. 

Hoy en día puedo decir que ha envejecido "regular", ya que si bien sigue siendo entretenido el paso del tiempo no le ha sentado del todo bien. Los controles no siempre responden como uno quiere, haciendo que terminemos saltando al vacío o dándonos de cara contra una pared, y el sistema de peleas es tan tosco que resulta frustrante, pero de todos modos no deja de ser una buena experiencia jugable. Hay momentos en los que logramos correr sin detenernos, esquivando y saltando obstáculos, acelerando cada vez más, de una forma tan fluida que se logra una muy buena sensación de vértigo. Que los desarrolladores hayan logrado que podamos sentir la velocidad de Faith en carne propia es el mayor acierto del juego.

Un inconveniente muy grave que le encuentro es que no está correctamente optimizado para ser jugado en PC's actuales con Sistema Operativo Windows 10. Internet está lleno de preguntas en foros donde se habla de problemas de crasheo luego del tutorial, problema que tuve y que después de una semana pude arreglar por mi cuenta ya que no hay ninguna solución oficial; uno no puede hacer menos que pensar que este título fue abandonado por completo por sus creadores (para quien lo necesite, mi solución fue buscar el ".exe" del juego y ejecutarlo en modo de compatibilidad con Windows XP Service Pack 2).

A pesar de sus problemas sigue siendo un buen juego que vale la pena jugar (si se encuentra el modo, ya que como dije, es probable que en equipos modernos presente inconvenientes)

I’d recommend this game in the end, but there were some really rough things in it honestly. Tutorial just felt very brief and didn’t explain some parkour mechanics you would use later in the game. Also, be prepared for some puzzle platforming. I wasn’t expecting it and it really took me some time to find the way to progress on the tougher levels. It detached from the story and action I think.

143726393.review: I'm sure this game is well enjoyed by people who have learned the mechanics well, but I struggled unbelievably hard with it. This game had me wanting to re-install Dying Light just to replay it's parkour. I had too many times where Faith didn't do what I wanted her to do, and did all the shit that I didn't want her to do. I will say that I didn't fully complete the tutorial, because it wouldn't let me progress despite doing exactly what it told me to do. The combat is also meh, I had so many instances where I couldn't get the counter-disarm shit right on time for the life of me, and you die in 3 shots practically anyways. Along with this, I had to fuckin deep dive into the files just to unlock my FPS and change the FOV so I can actually tell what I'm doing and where I am. I'm not sure if these changes had anything to do with it, or it was the PhysX shit (that I even turned off but didn't seem to change anything), but after this the game just started tabbing itself out randomly for a few seconds, then tabbing back in. I don't have to tell you that this isn't ideal for a parkour game. I know the game shits itself when the player tabs out (which I figured out instantly the hard way), but I didn't expect it to start doing it by its fucking self. All of this is to say, I want to enjoy this game, I really goddamn do. I've known about it for years and it was on sale so I thought why not play this game from the past. Little did I know. I've only written like 2 actual serious reviews where I say what I liked or disliked about the game in more than just 2 sentences, so trust me when I say this game had an impact on me. Maybe you'll like it, maybe the controls will work better for you, and maybe the game will work better for you. According to the internet the story is 6 hours long depending on how you play it, and I played the game for just under 4 hours, getting to the boat section with the snipers and explosive barrels when my issues arose. I don't think it's particularly long, so maybe only buy it if it's on sale. Hell, maybe I'll try this game again someday, and maybe it'll work.

143602748.review:
Cool atmosphere, the idea of a parkour game is fun, and the soundtrack is very neat.

But for the parkour mechanic to be fun, it has to actually work. And i can fairly say that 25% of the time you fall to your death, because the hit registration didn't trigger properly. And on your next attempt you do absolutely nothing different and OH BEHOLD suddenly it works...

Sometimes the level design is confusing. Making you stop running and forcing you to slowly look around for the correct path. Even with the hint system active. Which takes all the fun out of the parkour aspect, since for it to be fun, you need to feel a fluent flow in your movement. But the level design is often a hindrance to that.

There are MASSIVE fps drops. Even on my system, with hardware that is 10-12 years fresher than this games release and can handle far more modern and hardware hungry games, i still couldn't play certain parts without derping around at measly 10-20 frames per second. Pathetic.

I played through it once for the storys' sake a while ago and remember it was a chore. After upgrading parts of my system to better hardware i thought about giving the game another shot, but i just couldn't press on past chapter 4. Trying to fight or ignore the games flaws is just too bothersome. If a game makes me suffer, then it has to at least do that without the screen stuttering every other second.

143572617.review: A game that is by now likely to be of greater interest to gaming historians than current thrill-seekers.  Mirror's Edge unfolds over 9 well crafted-levels that provide progressive run-and-gun challenges, despite the game's reputation as strictly parkour.  The surreal art style and spare ambient score are worth experiencing: there are certainly worse ways to game than solving parkour puzzles in a visually appealing and occasionally spectacular setting.  The pacing of the game is occasionally jarring, and the narrative light, but overall the game stands up as a highly-polished and enjoyable genre piece.  It's good at what it does, and doesn't take longer than it needs: B+.

142519205.review:
This is the Game version of a "but when its good, its SOO good relationship."

Its a visionary Masterpiece with a clear vision that can be felt in every aspect, similar to Films like the Matrix or oldschool Luc Besson. The Game knows what it wants to be and makes hardly any compromises and I admire it for that.

But its also infuriating. 
Allmost every aspect has a frustrating clunkiness to it. The parkour is sometimes imprecise, the Level design msileading and the combat has its moments, but is so reduced and devoid from the core gameplay, that the game would have been better off without it.

But when its good, oh my god its good. Theres a tight racing game inside here, obsessed with flow and speed. You think and act with the speed of light, no latency between the two. Its intoxicating. 
theres also a movement puzzle which is the weaker part of the two, but still ahs a satisfying mix of problem solkving and execution, while being consistent with the core theme and mechanics.

I´m glad I had this experience. It was an intense summer romance, a thrilling adventure that I will allways cherish. But I´m also relieved that its over and probably won´t come back to it.

8/10

142114165.review:
Mirror's Edge, developed by DICE and published by Electronic Arts, is a breathtaking and innovative first-person action-adventure game that revolutionizes the genre with its unique parkour-based gameplay, stylized visuals, and immersive world. With its daring leaps, fluid movement, and intense chase sequences, Mirror's Edge stands as a true gem that pushes the boundaries of what a first-person game can be.

One of the standout features of Mirror's Edge is its groundbreaking parkour-based gameplay mechanics. Players assume the role of Faith, a skilled free runner in a dystopian city, as they navigate the vertigo-inducing rooftops, narrow corridors, and perilous obstacles with seamless grace and agility. The game's intuitive controls, responsive movement, and smooth animations allow players to perform stunning acrobatic maneuvers, such as wall running, sliding, and precise jumps, with a sense of freedom and exhilaration. The level design encourages creative exploration and rewards mastery of the fluid movement system, making every run a thrilling and immersive experience.

The visual design of Mirror's Edge is striking and distinctive, employing a minimalist aesthetic with bold and contrasting colors. The clean, white architecture of the cityscape serves as a canvas for the vibrant red objects and pathways that guide players through the environment. The visual style not only enhances the immersion but also reinforces the game's themes of rebellion and freedom. The animations and first-person perspective capture the intensity and rush of free running, giving players a sense of embodiment and immersion rarely found in other games.

The sound design in Mirror's Edge is equally exceptional. The ambient sounds of the city, the rush of wind as Faith soars through the air, and the rhythmic beats of the soundtrack all contribute to the game's immersive atmosphere. The absence of a traditional HUD and the emphasis on environmental audio cues add to the game's sense of immersion, heightening the player's focus and awareness of the surroundings.

Mirror's Edge also boasts a compelling storyline that explores themes of oppression, surveillance, and personal freedom. The narrative unfolds through beautifully animated cutscenes and in-game dialogue, providing context and motivation for Faith's actions. The voice acting is top-notch, with convincing performances that bring the characters to life and enhance the emotional impact of the story.

In addition to the main campaign, Mirror's Edge offers a time trial mode that challenges players to complete levels as quickly and efficiently as possible. The leaderboard system encourages friendly competition and replayability, as players strive to improve their times and master the intricacies of each level. The inclusion of community-created maps and challenges further extends the game's lifespan and offers fresh experiences for players to enjoy.

In conclusion, Mirror's Edge is a daring and innovative first-person action-adventure game that leaves a lasting impression with its parkour-based gameplay, stylish visuals, and immersive world. Its fluid movement mechanics, striking visual design, and captivating storyline make it a standout title in the genre. Whether you're a fan of thrilling action, immersive world-building, or simply seeking a unique gaming experience, Mirror's Edge delivers an exhilarating and unforgettable journey. Prepare to take a leap of faith, embrace the thrill of free running, and explore a future where freedom knows no bounds.

First of all, Faith's background story in the Comic book is gold, But the story of the game is straight up mud, they really didn't explore the story, the main character lore and the Mirror's edge universe, they really didn't do justice to it (they did a good job on the comics book issues, i recommend you read it online) but the character itself, if you read the comics, she has a good amount of depth and a solid background (the original comic was released almost together with mirror's edge 1) so they had a "solid" background to work with the main character, Faith, but they chose not to?, i have no idea why, maybe budget and time limitations?
But the game is still really enjoyable, the soundtrack and gameplay are still great till this day, i love the simplistic art design of the levels and the color pallets.
i played this game first when it was released (back in 2009) on xbox, i bought it again just to delight this piece of art of 2009 once again (quick tip, only buy this game on sale, you can buy it with mirror's edge catalyst in a bundle for a very cheap price 5 to 8 dollars).
this game, for a 2009 game is incredible and still holds up to this day.
The gameplay of the game is really enjoyable, the parkour is really fluid and incredible ( we are talking about a 2009 game here) the only 2 bad things about the game are, the combat is really bad, but you almost never fight, you can skip 90% of the enemies in this game, you can literally finish the game without killing or fighting anyone (besides Celeste Wilson if i'm not mistaken, she is the only one you really have to fight, i'm not counting that fat henchman, cuz you just have to parry his weapon) and the second bad thing about this game is, you can finish it in 4 and a half hours, so this game is not long.
Would i recommended this game although is old, and mirror's edge catalyst is out there? Yes, altough i enjoyed mirror's edge catalyst, i think mirror's edge 1 (graphics and open world aside here, let's make a fair comparison) is better, why? Faith Connors in mirror's edge catalyst moves like a paper clip, she doesn't feel heavy, the parkour feels more fluid but lifeless (compared to Mirror's edge 1, but still really good and enjoyable) , the combat still sucks in mirror's edge catalyst, so mirror's edge 1 is not really missing on that (but the combat in the second game is far superior) And Faith Connors in the first game, feels heavy, her movements, feels more like a human (opinions are my own).
So in my opinion Mirror's edge 1 is better gameplay wise but lacks the story, the depth of a open world and combat skill level up that Mirror's edge catalyst offers.
If you read the Mirror's edge 1 comic book, you can really start to "feel the game more" and understand it and have that "connection" to Faith's personality and her lore/universe, to play Mirror's edge 1 and really enjoy the game to its fullest, read the comics, trust me, it adds a lot to the game.
taking the comics in consideration (that is canon) Faith's personality is really mature and beautiful, especially for her age, after reading the comics you can really start to see why Faith in Mirror's edge 1 has that "closed face" "don't get near me, i trust no one" "back off" "conservative" personality, and why she became rebelious and developed that kind of personality, and why she's so mature for her age.
i hate Faith's personality in Mirror's edge catalyst, there's literally no depth, she's so less immature and bland for no reason (her background story is similar so there's no reason to) and she cries in front of others with her soaked face wanting acceptance from others, (like she did with that guy that had her mom's painting on the wall) Mirror's edge 1 Faith would never had thrown herself at the floor in front of other folks and cry and rant like she did.
what i'm trying to say is, Faith Connors have gone from your Bad b#tch nobody f##ks with me to your typical normie girl in the reboot. they really screwed up with her personality in the reboot, her personality is not faithful to the original story of the comics/lore.
and let's be honest here, Faith from Mirror's edge 1 is way more cute and beautiful by a mile, and she looks way more intimidating.
Rant aside, Buy the game (on sale) , is great, and read the comic online, to deepen and complement to the story, and to understand Faith's personality and her universe better. (The comics are canon to the Mirror's edge 1 universe)

Want a good parkour focused game? Buy it!
Want a good parkour focused game, a better game experience overall, and a half decent ingame story? buy mirror's edge catalyst instead. (or wait for a sale and buy both games in a bundle, it's really cheap)
Want a good story game? go find something else, or read the Mirror's edge comic book online!

141881117.review:
First person platforming or parkour games are very rare. Mirror’s Edge is often credited as one of the best. To some, it is. But, to others it can also become a sluggish and frustrating endeavor.

As a late 2000s era game, the clean and minimalist aesthetic of the game is quite gorgeous. The graphic holds up really well even years later. But, it’s also a double-edge sword. First time players could become confused with the lack of obnoxious landmarks or clear waypoints. The devs tried to mitigate this by having some interactive objects and background painted with visible primary colors, such as red, to nudge players toward a direction. There are also pigeons and rats as indicators Altough, in my playtrough with normal difficulty setting only some objects are painted to help me get a reading of a route. It didn’t help that I was constantly being shot at by polices and guards. The combat and shooting gameplay of this game is not very good compared to its traversal.

Compared to other games with parkour mechanism, such as Dyling Light and Assassin’s Creed that have assisted AIs or low margin for fail during platforming, Mirror’s Edge is quite raw and punishing especially for slow players. It asked you to be quick and decisive in split second or you will lose all the momentum. One can argue that it required good reflexes. I often failed and died trying to figure out platforming puzzles or the best route to escape. Once you have mapped everything (after dying many times) in your head tough, it can be quite exhilarating.

The story is forgettable and doesn’t make much sense. It has 8-9 levels that you can finish in short period. Even for me that often failed and had to retry a lot, it’s indeed quite short. It leaves a lot to be desired. But, at least Mirror’s Edge didn’t overstay its welcome.

141112203.review:
Mirror's Edge is a parkour-platformer game where you play as a runner named Faith, trying to free her sister who is framed for a murder, becoming a fugitive herself in the process. Most of the game is spent running on foot while making awesome moves such as wall-running. There are enemies, but since it's not that kind of game you cannot take too many hits. Better hit them one-on-one or perform an instant knockout disarm.

One of the things that stand out the most, other than being a great parkour game, are the level's aesthetics. They are minimalistic, yet very eye-catching, typically using bright colors such as blue and yellow on white walls or floors. It makes the hallways a pleasure to travel through since they're not the usual boring gray or brown colors. And that's a very good thing, since most levels are just hallways and rooftops.

However, the game's minimalist style contributes to its shortcomings. The levels feel too empty, you very rarely meet characters outside of cutscenes. The supposedly bustling city feels as empty as the test chambers in Portal. And since it discourages combat, the final confrontation with the antagonist felt rushed and unsatisfying. There will also be no sequel, as Mirror's Edge Catalyst is a reboot.

For its age, Mirror's Edge is a surprisingly well-made, fast-paced parkour game, and definitely a title you should play if you are into parkours and platformers. I can say the parkour is better than Dying Light, but then again it's not a pure parkour game. If you enjoyed the parkour in DL you are sure to enjoy it here, just don't expect a grappling hook to help you traverse.

140660489.review:
The biggest system in the game by far, which is the parkour system, since that is 99% of what you will be doing, doesn't even work right. It has the same exact problem with platforming I've seen so many times in other games, all of which mainly just boil down to things failing horribly to register or detect. For example, when jumping off a ledge, the jump key will usually not register so you fail to jump and fall and die. Now go repeat an entire section only to die 10 more times until the game finally decides to register your jump. This also happens with things like detecting a roll at the end of a fall to avoid taking damage, which basically never worked for me. 

There is combat, which is also terribly janky. The game tells you to literally avoid it wherever possible, which turns out to be good advice. Except other times it makes it seem like fighting is mandatory. Until you realize that even in those sections you can just avoid it. Which is confusing, but I guess its also cool that there are different ways to play. 

But when both of those ways are bad, there really is nothing left to like about it. The story isn't interesting and the art style is bizarre mix of minimalism and highly saturated contrast. Even with brightness and contrast at the lowest levels, most of the game is blindingly white, while dark areas like vents are pitch black. You can turn up the brightness to navigate the dark areas, but then the outside areas get even more eye-searing. After a while I got sick of having to open the menu constantly and change the settings, so I just left them on low and stumbled through the darkness like a blind bat, which is fine I guess since those areas are rare. But the game is still boring to look at because everything is one color: white. Here and there are tinges of blue, red, yellow, etc. but you rarely see more than one of these colors together at once. If I had to guess, its because "of an abstract art direction that ties deeply into the game's themes" or some other typical corpo excuse for spending less money on the game. Which is consistent with the low budget anime quality of the cutscenes. 

Pass on this one. I got it for 2 bucks and don't even want to finish it.

Years ago, I couldn't get further than two hours into this game. It was heavy, directionless, and overwhelmingly grounded. I'd constantly trip over my feet, and it became grating to an unbearable extent.

Years later, I've beaten the game multiple times and completed every time trial. The movement emulates the perfect parkour fantasy-- It's light, free-form, and grounded. When I fail a jump, it's almost always my fault, and the satisfaction of perfecting a run will never get old.

Speaking of, Mirror's Edge came out in 2008, and it still looks incredible.

140156291.review:
Before I mention the game itself, I’m going to say that the PC port for this game is not the greatest. The options menu is lacking in basic functionality to the point it may as well not exist at all. It might not be fair to compare it to modern releases, but it is being sold as a product so I think it’s worth mentioning.

The port has few ways to tweak the game or how it runs. There’s no way to change stuff like sound effect volume or how Faith (the main character) feels to play. You can’t disable blur effects on their own, you have to turn the graphical quality to low to achieve this. The difficulty option appears to only change how easy combat is. You can’t make platforming or parkour harder or easier to accomplish, which is primarily what you’ll be doing 90% of the time.

The game uses red and orange to signpost what parts of the environment (chairs, walls, etc) can be scaled or vaulted from to reach new areas. It would've been a great idea to let the player change the colours to suit visual impairments. The game can still be played without these modifiers, but it certainly would've been a good inclusion. 

I get that accessibility options like this were not commonplace in 2008, but it does feel like a glaring omission nowadays. I also had severe screen tearing that I could only fix by forcing vsync through NVIDIA’s control panel. For some odd reason, the in-game option did not function at all.

None of this stuff was a massive deal breaker for me, just keep in mind that the PC port is not the best.

Technical babble aside, does Mirror's Edge hold up in 2023? Well, it's a bit more complicated than a simple yes or no answer, but I think it's fine considering the age and legacy of the game. It is also understandably dated in many ways. I think it has aged well graphically..mostly. It has a sleek, futuristic white coat for most buildings which fits the dystopia the game takes place in. The colour palette is basic but is easy to read, provided you can see the colours white, red and orange. There’s an overuse of bloom and an eye piercing amount of light at times, but it looks remarkably good for a game this old.

I’m not going to discuss the story or themes of the game because, to be kind, it isn't very interesting or worth much discussion. It is predictable and simple. The game is about finding and rescuing your sister who has been framed for the the murder of a Mayoral candidate. It isn't a bad story I just didn't care for what was happening and it is serviceable enough in getting you to go from point A to B, which is all the story needed to be.

Parkour is the main novelty of this game and while I did like the parkour in Mirror’s Edge, I did not grow to love it. Faith moves in a way that is hard to easily summarise in text, but her jumps are heavy and weighty, unlike other platform games. You can’t correct during the middle of a jump which means you are committing to it every time, so falling to your death can happen if you aren't careful.

Even maintaining momentum can be awkward and clumsy, but I sort of appreciate what the developers were going for, even if it was not my cup of tea 100% of the time.

The game is not a simulator that is trying to accurately depict parkour, but I think the point was to match the *feel* of parkour without making the game even more technical. The problem is that it can feel clunky and counterintuitive, especially to a modern audience. The parkour didn’t really click for me until the halfway point, but I sort of grew to enjoy what it was, rather than what it was not. It can be difficult to make certain jumps or maintain momentum, but it can feel rewarding precisely because it requires mastery of the controls to get the most out if it. I failed a lot during my time playing, but the game usually has decent enough checkpoints that retrying isn’t much of an issue and I eventually got better. It does take practice and a dash of patience, though.

Unfortunately, the missions themselves are hit or miss. They are well designed from a practical basis. The city looks real enough despite there being no people living in it, unless you count armed guards? But from a gameplay perspective they don’t always mesh well with the platforming. I feel like parkour in this game is fantastic when it all comes together, when you speed past enemies and make death defying jumps. The problem is that most missions have a start and stop element which drags the experience down for me. I don’t think the game benefits from having you run from 6 armed guards in one moment to slowly exploring a mall and getting lost in the next. When the game doesn’t come together, you’ll be lost and fumbling around looking for where to go next which kills the pacing of most missions.

I could also complain about how much of a burden the combat system is. You can kick, punch, slide kick and dropkick. This sounds cool but it doesn’t really amount to much, the game makes it pretty clear that you should avoid combat. If you are unlucky enough to get spotted by an armed guard, which happens 100% of the time because they are programmed to spot you as soon as you enter certain areas or a hidden timer has passed. At that point, your best bet is to run or take a guard's gun and slowly take out the rest of the hit squad that has come after you.

I would usually flee because combat is typically an exercise in frustration. There’s no way to guard or dodge so combat is just you awkwardly throwing out limbs and praying the guard goes down quickly before Faith does. Running is usually safer, but this has its own unique set of problems. Primarily, knowing where to go to make progress. Most of my game overs were me scrambling around a facility, hitting a dead end or not fully understanding where to go next. I would then be swarmed by a hit squad and die quickly. I eventually got better at the game but I guarantee the first dozen deaths you have will be like this. 

You can press left ALT to get an approximation of where to head, which just jerks the camera in a direction with zero markings or on screen identifiers, but it’s something. I did not mind deaths where I was clearly making mistakes. Failing a jump and plummeting 100ft to the concrete floor or being gunned down after failing to take out a guard is one thing. Running around like a fool for 30 seconds only to be met with a dead end was a recurring issue that only resulted in a 12 minute story mission almost doubling in length, precisely because of trial and error and some obtuse level design. I get that the developers wanted people to replay the missions so that they could master the more intricate parts, but on a first run it didn't really add to the experience for me.

I did ramble about a few negatives, but I’d still recommend Mirror’s Edge in 2023 (and beyond, assuming the game isn't removed from Steam) to certain groups of people.

If you are patient and can play what might feel like a glorified tech demo, showcasing a novel concept then you will probably like this game. If you can appreciate demanding platforming challenges or the speedrunning legacy this game has left us with, then you will also be a good fit for this game. On the other hand, if you hate trial and error game design, suffer from motion sickness or hate being stuck or lost, then you might want to think carefully before picking the game up.

139698882.review:
Un juego que en su momento fue una revolución, pero que si lo juegas hoy en día te darás cuenta de que es mucho peor de lo que recordabas.

Es básicamente un simulador de parkour, con un par de mecánicas de combate muy básicas y mal implementadas, y que, sobretodo en mi caso que lo jugué poco después de haber jugado a la siguiente entrega de la saga, pierde todo su sentido que sea en un formato por niveles y no en un mundo abierto.

La historia es muy simple y bastante irrelevante, su parkour es un poco tosco y poco disfrutable a día de hoy, su combate es tan malo que no resulta una opción viable nunca, y que te obliga a huir siempre, y por desgracia eso es todo lo que tiene este juego.

Visualmente parece un juego de PS2 o incluso anterior, unos modelados dignos de los juegos de Harry Potter antiguos y unos píxeles que parece que se te ha roto la pantalla del ordenador. Lo peor es que está tan mal optimizado en sí que si lo juegas en otras plataformas como Steam Deck, mientras que las cinemáticas y pantallas de carga se ven geniales, todo el resto del juego se ve como si te tuvieses que graduar de nuevo las gafas, una experiencia ciertamente horrible.

Lo único bueno de este juego es que su existencia permitió la salida de su siguiente entrega, que es una jodida obra de arte y que arregla todos los aspectos en que este juego fracasó estrepitosamente. No lo recomiendo en absoluto, jugad al siguiente directamente porque además la historia no tiene nada que ver.

139624288.review:
7.5/10

Took me about 8.5 hours to finish. 
A pretty fun time, and one of the more unique action games of it's time. The writing isn't anything to write home about, but the game really shines in its parkour mechanics and level design. Running through the city, jumping from trains, to rooftops, to ziplines and crashing through windows at a fast pace provides an incredible adrenaline rush. 

The world and it's use of color was fascinating, and is just really nice to look at even to this day.

The game also has some great replay value with it's Speedruning and Time Trial modes, as well as plenty of hidden collectibles to find in every level.

I will say that the level design in the second half of the game could be a bit frustrating at times, sometimes spending a few minutes figuring out where the heck I'm supposed to be going, which breaks the momentum you should be feeling when playing the game.

As mentioned earlier, the story wasn't very memorable in my opinion. It's only been an hour since I beat it and I'm already having trouble recalling the plot. At best it's written as a really generic action thriller.

Despite those flaws, I can't help but look at Mirror's Edge with nothing but enthusiasm. The game has style, and it certainly does its best to make you feel like you've got it too.

139609339.review:
It's okay but

Mirror's Edge promises you the vast skyline, the sprawling rooftops, all this wonderful space to move around in but then hampers that freedom with mandatory combat sequences. That's not to say ALL of them are bad, for example there is a section where you are trying to reach the bottom of a building, and if you think like a Runner, you can swiftly weave through the enemies and descent before they can even land a shot on you. That's the key word, Runner; the game tries so hard to make you feel like a Runner, but when Merc is telling you to get out of there, and there are 3 dudes camping the slow ass pipe to climb up, you have reject Runner and return to Gunner.
And the enemies don't always carry guns, in some cases it could be tiny room with messy geometry that slows you down. A key point of selling to you the feeling of being a Runner is seeing the world through the Runner's eye. The problem is half way through Faith's be getting that protanopia, but that's okay, because at this point you HAVE the runner's eye. Players should be subconsciously feeling out which objects they can climb and which they can't, which is what parkour is all about. But then they had to go ahead and just subvert everything, pipes sometimes can be climbed up, other times not, ledges are less than pronounced, goal camera that points to the opposite side of the map while needing the player to first backtrack to the previous room to get higher up before proceeding. Many of the problems felt like they could have been solved had the player been able to see the entire section of the parkour level, where instead of being frustrated at not knowing where to go, it could empower you to actually overcome what's in front of you. Which, ironically the game did do during one of the more open areas, but then immediately funnelled into a small linear corridor.

139408000.review:
Mirrors edge is a first person action game where you play the role as Faith, a person known as a “runner”.

Your sister has been framed for murder and you have also been targeted by police to be shot on sight. Your missions range from gathering information, tracking people of interest, and fighting off police.

While the story is decent, the best part about the game is probably the parkour. Your character moves fluidly across the entire landscape, and the jumping, wall running, and sliding all look and feels great.
But there’s some issues with the game I did not like……..

The combat- it sucks. You can punch some enemies but they have guns and usually come in groups of 4+ so more times than not you will be killed quickly trying to understand the best way to deal with them.
Once you get a gun from the enemy it’s pretty easy from that point on to kill all the enemies and proceed.

The level design - while the levels look good they are also annoying as hell to navigate at times. There’s too many points in the game where you must make this critical jump that you will barely make but you end up dying a dozen times because you are always an inch short. This becomes frustrating when you have a few enemies shooting you with laser accuracy and you die midair at last jump. 

Graphically the game still looks nice for being 14yrs old. It actually looks better than some recent games in the last 5 years.
The voice acting is also very good.

Overall it was a decent game even with its frustrating moments and was fun to sprint across the rooftops while jumping and sliding like a ninja

I played on steam deck and had no issues at max settings 60fps at all times.

You can regularly find this game for 3.00 on sale and it’s worth it

7/10

139376166.review:
[h1]Mirror's Edge is still great in 2023[/h1]

[b]I bought this game at 90% off for just under £2 with no clue of anything about the game apart from that I was told it's definitely worth playing. I've written a bit and added a chart underneath.[/b]
Probably the best <£2 game i've ever played, the motion and gameplay is like nothing else I've seen before and you genuinely feel like you're inside and a part of the game rather than just someone playing. Graphics are still great even though it's (iirc) almost 14 years old, and runs well on low and high-spec stuff. If I bought it again I'd pay full price for this but if it's ever on sale again its a [b]steal[/b]. Other things that are nice are the scenery and views that don't kill your CPU, RAM or GPU, since I was running on Intel Iris Xe graphics as part of an i7. If you like parkour and fps then this is for you. My only problem is it can freeze out a little bit if you change tabs but this is extremely minor and I'd barely call it a bug.

139367392.review:
The most noteworthy aspect of Mirror's Edge is undeniably its gameplay. This game is the forerunner in the genre of first-person parkour games, and in my opinion, remains the best. The movement mechanics feel fluid and modern.

For a game from 2009 the graphics are really good and look beautiful. The atmosphere of the game world in Mirror's Edge is really great as well. The game is set in a city that has a really special feel to it, accompanied with outstanding music.  Both the atmosphere and the music give me a certain feeling of wonder I cannot describe. 

While the storyline may not be the most memorable aspect of the game, it certainly isn't lackluster. The narrative provides a decent backbone to the gameplay, though it doesn't particularly stand out as the game's strongest point. 

The combat mechanics in Mirror's Edge are satisfactory, although they are not particularly groundbreaking. Despite not being the main focus of the game, the combat encounters can still prove to be enjoyable and satisfying. 

On the downside, Mirror's Edge could be criticized for its relatively short playtime. This limitation, however, doesn't detract significantly from the overall experience.

I definitely recommend this game

139346095.review:
Sinceramente, me he llevado una grata sorpresa en este maravilloso viaje que es Mirror's Edge.
Un juego que en su día de pequeño me llamó la atención, pero al final no lo pude disfrutar, en esa época no tenía PC y no me lo pude pillar para la PS3, pero a día de hoy puedo decir que mi yo niño esta muy contento de haber disfrutado de esta experiencia.
Si lo tuviera que describir con una palabra sería infravalorado, quizás dejado de lado ya que en noviembre del 2008 que es cuando salió a la venta, juegos como Gears of War 2, World of Warcraft: Wrath of the Litch King y Call of Duty: World At War fueron lanzados al mercado justo en ese mismo mes. 
De todos modos, es un juego muy especial, ubicado en una ciudad utópica futurista pero sin llegar a ser ciencia ficción, sino más bien una ciudad con muchos avances tecnológicos que hoy en día existen y son posibles y con una estética muy limpia, agradable y con una paleta de colores muy simple pero muy efectiva ya que es su manera de comunicarse con el jugador a la hora de jugar e interactuar con el entorno.
Una de las cosas que más me atraen es que las cinemáticas que tiene están hechas con un estilo cartoon que algunas veces te recuerda al Art Decó. A mí personalmente me gusta muchísimo ese estilo, y además no abusan de cinemáticas, que es algo también muy a tener en cuenta a la hora de disfrutar del juego y de la historia que te presentan.
En cuanto a personajes, tenemos a Faith, que se va a quedar siempre en  mi corazón de jugador, con una personalidad muy fuerte y se nota que los guionistas trabajaron mucho para desarrollarla bien y darle un background muy bueno, y sobre todo sin sexualizar al personaje ya que en la gran mayoría de veces en los viodejuegos los personajes femeninos tienden a sexualizar, y esto es algo que se agradece mucho porque es un soplo de aire fresco. El resto de personajes están igual de bien tratados por los guionistas, haciendo que en todo momento la historia tenga un sentido y les cojas mucho cariño a algunos, y a otros mejor me reservo el comentario de odio...
Por otro lado, la banda sonora que tiene me parece excelente ya que es muy agradable de escuchar y no satura para nada haciendo que sea relajante la mayoría del tiempo, y tensa en los momentos críticos del juego.
Me gustaría comentar algo que me ha parecido muy notorio, y es que para ser un juego del 2008, tiene una iluminación flipante y muy pulida, de hecho hay bastantes juegos posteriores a Mirror's Edge más modernos, y ni se acercan al trabajo de iluminación que tiene este juego. 
Es un juego que ha sido muy castigado ya que lo acusan de ser muy lineal, de corta duración y con un sistema de combate muy pobre, y la verdad es que es un videojuego que en su día fue completamente distinto a lo que estaba acostumbrado el consumidor medio a jugar, y se atrevió con mecánicas que en esa época eran algo revolucionario. El combate es cierto que es lo peor que tiene el juego, porque se nota muy pesado y sin que el jugador reciba un feedback en las peleas, pero quitando eso se queda una historia excelente y mecánicas, que te pueden gustar más o menos, muy interesantes y divertidas.
Sin duda es una obra atemporal que es completamente disfrutable 15 años después, y que recomiendo encarecidamente a cualquier tipo de jugador.
Mi más sincera enhorabuena a DICE por el pedazo de juego que es Mirror's Edge.

139255669.review:
TLDR: Nah fam

Mirror's Edge is an odd experience. The movement at first can feel exciting, but quickly I found it repetitive given the level design. Moving your camera left or right will slow you down, but also using the arrow keys will make you dodge. The issue with such design game play wise is that any type of turn will get you to lose all of your momentum that you had built up from a few seconds ago when you hadn't had to deal with turning. With that in mind, the game decides to turn the levels into almost mazes, (it's the reason why this game has the "Puzzle" tag so high). The levels quickly just become massive halts as you slowly have to navigate a whole giant room to figure out where the next place you need to go is, completely halting that whole feeling of speed that this game is going for. 

This game is very pretty, especially given that this was made in 2009. The world design was done very well, which makes it more unfortunate just because of how much of a slog it can become when your stuck in just a grey box for two minutes instead of running through colourful rooftops and hallways. The worlds are colourful most of the time, but again, quickly as you're stopped on every single wall on the later levels it can quickly become very repetitive and samey. This game isn't very long, but by my 2-3rd hour or so, the world design was completely faded for me and instead it was just my mind focusing more on how awful some of these rooms and levels are designed. Example: One room in particular I remember being awful was in the level "The Drains". There are a bunch of concrete poles that come from the floor to the roof, and at first it looks pretty then becomes a nightmare. It's the same jump, over and over and over again copy and pasted for probably more then 50 times given the amount of platforms. It gives you no direction as to where to go, I actually found the secret first just because going forward ended up not being the right way. (You had to go halfway to the middle of the bottom, then go all the way left until you reach a ladder that is hidden on the back of one of the dreaded platforms).

The last main big discussion point that should be INTENDED with this game is combat. It completely falls flat, getting hit feels underwhelming. Punches? They'll hit you and make your screen go a little grey. Bullets? They will literally just go through you with no indication, you have to be holding your camera downwards just to see a small blood splat that indicates you got shot. Aside from the enemies, the game also has you battling and doing combat. You're punches are weak, every move you do will hit for the same, so there is no reason to go for any cool wall runs or anything when you can literally just kick them in the face and call it a day. You're also able to pick up guns from enemies, this can be done via disarming your enemy which you can tell when to do by when the gun shines red mid swing. (Sometimes guns will literally forget to glow red, just hit you through the disarm, or you might even just die from an invisible melee attack mid cut scene).

This game could have been a decent experience, but in my whole 5 hours of playing this game, I had to restart my computer 3 times due to alt + tabbing and the game not understanding what that means and just freezing the whole PC. This is common with older games, but I just thought I should mention it in case anyone was not aware. Aside from that, I sometimes would just run into invisible walls, run through walls or fall through the floor, and last but not least just get stuck inside of a box with literally nothing you can do, (the game gives you no way to restart from checkpoints). 

If you really feel like playing this game, just get it on console, this game is just to buggy on PC given the time that this has been rotting away with no updates. I remember when I played this on my Xbox, most of those same bugs were there, but at least I was able to access the home menu and other things without having to completely restart the thing. ^^;

139227541.review:
Fantastic First person platformer. The aesthetic choices still make the game look incredible almost 15 years later. The parkour system is simple, super fun, and satisfying. Story is pretty cliche and characters are bare-bones. However, the animations between levels had a nice aesthetic and the story rarely interrupts gameplay so I never felt bored or frustrated with it. 

The biggest problem with this game is the combat system. Unfortunately it's just super dated and janky. Fighting enemies is more of an exercise of frustration rather than a cool mix of parkour and CQC. The worst example of this is the bossfight with the female ninja. The whole section just left me irritated. 

All-in-all, the aesthetics and parkour of this game more than make up for the lacklustre feel of the combat. Gliding across rooftops, wallrunning into a leap to get across a gap, and quickly sliding down pipes to make getaways are exhilarating, and  the reason this game left it's mark on me.
