139204407.review:
I've played through Mirror's Edge several times over the years—both on PC and console—and it has never failed to leave an impression on me.  The basic premise is that you're an information runner that excels in speedily traversing the environment and avoiding combat with those that pursue you.  Unfortunately the game works better in theory than it often does in practice so Mirror's Edge does come with a bit of jank, primarily in the form occasionally clumsy controls and fickle game responsiveness that when combined result in a lot of pointless and avoidable deaths.

Mirror's Edge is the type of game that excels when it encourages player freedom and creativity, so it's annoying that it so often wants to force you into awkward combat scenarios equipped with nothing more than half-baked first-person combat mechanics or punish you when it mercilessly decides to misinterpret your wall run maneuver as a point-blank nosedive into the cold concrete beneath you, thus forcing you to replay a short section of the game—sometimes multiple times—as you try to figure out just exactly what it is that the game wants from you.  Mirror's Edge sometimes feels like a game that knows exactly what kind of game it wants to be yet is constantly and actively working against itself at all times to prevent itself from being exactly that.  Faith has a few basic attacks: some punches, a slide kick, and a wall run kick that can be used to fend off enemies, but these resources often fail in comparison to your heavily armoured foes and their firearms.  There are few practical uses for the wall run kick to ever truly be useful, and the slide kick can be tricky to time right if you activate it too early and stop short of your enemy.  There's a disarm maneuver that can be used against enemies that try to melee you and stolen or picked up weapons can be used to gun down any remaining enemies.  It's both neat and bizarre that Mirror's Edge features usable guns in the first place.  I like the fact that I can pick up the weapons from my foes to use them in a fit of desperation, but it's clear that the design team made certain sections with the deliberate intent of forcing the player into weapon-based combat, which seems to be at odds with the game's overall design principles.  I think a system that gave players the choice to engage in firearms as just another option while also outfitting them with better tools to take on or avoid enemies in other ways would have contributed to the game's objective of having a dynamic, player-choice driven gameplay experience.  It would have been nice if Faith had some kind of rechargeable instant takedown mechanic, or a limited use stun weapon that made combat less frustrating and feel more rewarding.  I appreciate lethally armed enemies as a source of upping the stakes and making the threat feel very real, but as combat with them exists in the game it's often more of a source of momentum-halting frustration than the euphoria-inducing high of narrowly escaping death that it was meant to be.  Faith has a limited use ability that slows time down to a crawl, which is primarily used for disarming enemies more easily in close quarters combat.  It seems like a missed opportunity that this ability was never implemented in such a way that it allows Faith to slow down the gunfire and movement of her enemies while she moves at a slightly faster speed that allows the player to navigate their way to safety more easily.  There's a few moments in the game that end up feeling a bit too much like trial and error due to the aggressiveness of enemies combined with not knowing exactly where to go.  Having more tools to avoid, stun, or outright combat enemies more reliably without dying, or having to resort to a pure old-fashioned gunfight every single time, would go a long way in preserving the momentum of the moment-to-moment gameplay while simultaneously avoiding unnecessary player deaths caused by a game that actively discourages combat by design at every opportunity, yet consistently forces the player into situations where there are seemingly no other alternatives.

To alleviate some of this frustration there's runner vision—an option which can be enabled or disabled freely in the menus that highlights key interactable objects in bright red as you near them.  I prefer playing with runner vision turned off, as this is the kind of game that excels when it encourages player freedom and experimentation, but leaving it enabled does help in alleviating some frustration for new players playing for the first time.

Mirror's Edge is at its best when it's not throwing enemies at you and simply leaves you alone to discover its world and traverse its serenely sterile environments in peace.  I find that since the focus of the game is not meant to be on combat that playing the game on easy difficulty makes it a much more enjoyable experience.  The difficulty slider primarily dictates how quickly enemies can kill you and has no other effect otherwise on the much more important puzzle aspect of the game.  For a game that came out for PC in early 2009 it's a masterclass audiovisual experience.  The art design and soundtrack are both phenomenal and elevate the game to another level.  These aspects make Mirror's Edge much more important as an experience for those that appreciate the artistic aspect of games rather than placing more importance on the perfected mechanical side of the equation.  If you appreciate games as not just something you play but also as something that you experience then Mirror's Edge ranks amongst the best experiences there are.  Every time the journey ends and the credits roll I'm always left with the same irreplaceable feeling of satisfaction that I get from watching an incredible or one of my personal favourite films.

Mirror's Edge is a game that was ahead of its time; it features a unique world and gameplay concept, interesting (albeit light) commentary on a surveillance-obsessed Orwellian society that increasingly resembles our own, an outstanding soundtrack, and a diverse cast of characters that don't feel like pretentious and unimaginative virtue signaling cardboard cutouts. Yet it's also a game that's flawed, and it wears those flaws on its sleeves, and in spite of those flaws it's all the better for it.

139114657.review:
Are you a fan of parkour games that have the wonkiest, most inconsistent controls you've ever used? Have you ever been playing a platformer and thought: "this game is fun, it it would be more fun if I was surrounded by a firing squad at literally every moment of it"? Then mirrors edge is for you. If you're not a masochist, play something else.

In all seriousness, I want to like this game so much. When the controls are working, and when your not getting shot, it's an incredibly fun experience. But frequently throughout the game, the parkour mechanics fail. Things you think you should land, you just don't. Jumps you should make, you barley make half way. It's incredibly annoying to deal with.

If it was just some fiddly controls, I'd be able to set it aside, because as I said, when they work, it's really fun. And they work well enough for you to play around the occasional fiddly moment. But for some reason, every single mission in this game ends up with you getting pinned down by trigger happy cops, spraying their unlimited ammo in your direction. It makes the game next to unplayable. If you hesitate for even a moment, you die. Did the controls break and make you fail a jump? Dead. Did you take a second to look around for where to go next? Dead. Did you stop to catch your breath at any point in the non stop chasing? Dead. I get having some levels where your being chased, it can be a fun action scene to have to quickly parkour through an area, dodging fire. But when literally every level becomes a cop chase, it becomes much more an annoyance than a cool set piece. Some levels will start with just letting you find your way through an area, and those are super fun! but inevitably, you'll end up once again being chased down by the omnipresent cops, and their endless budget for bullets and helicopters.

139053566.review:
I've completed Mirror's Edge twice, but since I lost access to the account I initially purchased it on I decided to pick it up on Steam as well; for a mere two dollar (simply because it's published by EA).

This game is a complete anomaly. It's hard to describe it as anything else. Even though it was released in 2008, at which point we were already knee-deep in the corporate shitshow that is the gaming industry today Mirrors Edge came to fruition. And published by EA out of all publishers. Of course these were the glory days for DICE, which eventually also got drained of its soul as all developers that signed a contract with the devil.

Mirror's Edge is a game that follows no rules but its own. It's defiant in how different it is than other titles released at the time, especially those that sold well. And the resulting vision that the game turned out to be is a true genre defining classic.

The abstract title also aligns with the overall aesthetic of the game, which to this day is probably my favorite in any game I've played since (which are by now literal thousands of titles). It achieves a distinct futuristic look by contrasting bold colors to white backdrops, which, in an almost poetic way is very similar to the game itself. The effect this achieves is incredible visual clarity at a whim, even though it is utilized fairly poorly too often. It's unique, it serves a clear purpose and when it works there's no substitute. Just *chef's kiss*.

The gameplay is very smooth, requiring minimal inputs but making good use of the few keys they do use. Even though sporadic combat is a brilliant addition to the game on paper (make me) it is executed very poorly. Combat would be a free ticket to breaking the monotony of the parkour, flowing seamlessly with both the story and existing gameplay as is. Unfortunately it's just really janky and isn't integrated properly into the flow of the game. More comically Faith can even go as far as to pick up large sniper rifles and start blasting baddies with it. It's hilariously out of touch with the tone of the game.

Even though the parkour WAS the golden standard, it starts to show signs of age. Faith has the cardio of a greek god, but she does compensate for it by being as slow as a 300lbs dockworker. It's not necessarily bad as it allows players to actually pick up on cues as they progress, but it kind-of takes away from the pacing (unsurprisingly). The momentum system is of-course very smart, but the game makes so little use of it. Instead it attempts to be more of a "THINK FAST"-type of game, rather than one that is very execution heavy. The optimal formula would probably be something in the middle, primarily considering accessibility as a main concern.

The music is all done by Solar Fields and I would be lying if I were to claim Still Alive didn't bring a tear to my eye, and another one several years later due to sheer nostalgia. The tracks are fitting and add to the game's unique vibe even if they aren't all that special in reality.

Unfortunately Mirror's Edge's sequel was a disaster to me - and even though I was completely flabbergasted EA would give the green to it in first place (due to the mediocre sales on the first installment) the result was more or less as expected. Ubitrash had been making money with easy copy-paste overworlds so EA was having a slice of that. Why they chose Mirror's Edge as the most appropriate victim to their corporate trash I'm unsure of, but the result was a wholly uninspired mess I prefer to forget about.

Mirror's Edge is a true classic and one of the most noteworthy triple A titles ever produced. It's not perfect by any stretch of the imagination, but a sudden bold thought provoking statement completely out of the blue. An excellent design study and will forever be one of my most adored games.

139015384.review:
[b] An average game that tried its hardest to burn my eyes [/b]

First off, the game is extremely hard to navigate and in a game that incentivizes running through levels as fast as possible being hard to navigate is bad, if not detrimental. It doesn't help that the bloom is absolutely atrocious and overbearing and the "runner vision" which was supposed to help you navigate is slow to appear, that is if you notices its appearance. However, the "runner vision" only highlights the environment and it is sometimes hard to know what the game wants you to go when you get to the highlighted environment, whether it is move forward or look back, left or right. Sure, it takes a few seconds of looking around and pressing the "alt" key to get the game to point to where you need to be but that just destroys the flow. Some levels have enemies come in to shoot at you, so you get lost in the level while enemies are riddling you with bullets.

When there are enemies with guns, you can disarm them and use their weapons but disarming enemies is a chore, you can only disarm when the weapon turns red, not when the enemy is rearing back to slap you with it and the time frame for disarming is quite quick so you'd have to rely on the slow motion mode to help with it. However, when you press the disarm button sooner than you're supposed to, Faith will play out the whole failed disarm animation which is enough time for the enemy to slap you and if you pressed the slow motion button before hand, you'd have to wait the entire duration of seeing the failed animation and then being slapped back all in slow motion because you can't disable the slow motion and have to wait til it is over.

But once you get the gun, Faith isn't the best at handling it. It's clunky and slows Faith down quite a bit so Dice might as well not bother with letting Faith use a gun.

Have I mentioned that the bloom is atrocious. I don't know about anybody else but the bloom actually made me have a splitting headache. I physically can not play the game for an extended period of time because it is unbearably nauseating. It's especially bad during the level where you're on a white painted roof that is surrounded by white painted buildings and it was like a supernova happening on my screen. I'm literally blinded by the lights. I can't seem to turn it off even if I disabled it in the files.

The parkour, main selling point, is quite slow. Sometimes, Faith will grab onto a ledge with one hand then slowly reaches the other one up and THEN can you tell her to climb up. Switching pipes sometimes don't work because I phase through pipes and plunged to my death. Sliding is also slow as well and there's no rolling after a slide to regain lost momentum like in Catalyst. 

Conclusion: It is a flawed game, extremely so. It is still unique for its time and have quite possibly set the foundation for many game that follows in its footsteps like its own sequel/prequel Catayst and Dying Light. However, those games are far more enjoyable than its predecessor. Mirror's Edge Catalyst have taken that foundation and built on it, it made the parkour snappier and faster thus never ruining the flow along with plenty of parkour move that you could chain together into combos which add to the flow of navigation, the "runner vision" being a clear line for you to follow which made it hard for you to get lost (though sometimes it can just straight up disappear), combat is easier and you can better chain parkour into combat (Mirror's Edge kinda has this but the execution is lacking); Dying Light's gameplay is more varied. And most importantly, Dying Light and Catalyst never blinds you with its atrocious bloom effect.

138864809.review:
Mirror's Edge is a first person perspective, adventure parkour game starring the female lead - Faith and her trusty helper Merc, battling mysterious and shady figures, as well as "the blues"(A.K.A. the police). Parkour is the main focus of the game - jumping from high spaces, wall riding, tightrope walking and more, as you try to find out why the police started acting so agressive towards Faith and the Runners, and furthermore uncovering a larger scheme in the works. The game will tell in you in the begining to avoid fights, but towards the end of the game, there is no avoiding and you can pick up weapons, which is where the game becomes a bit of a shooter, although the shooting mechanics are not there (no aiming, except for the sniper and the other weapons have recoil, you can't reload weapons).

The game was developed by DICE (most know for Battlefield) and published by EA. The game takes rougly 6-8 hours to beat, depending on how much time you spend trying to find your way through the levels, as the game does not sport a HUD, but objects that you can use - glow in red (this option is called Runners Vision and it can be disabled), but in general, you have no guide or arrow that points through the right way, but with a press of a button, you can see where is your next objective (in case you get lost). Apart from the main story, the game has trials, and a speed run mode for the campaign, if you want more parkour-ing. Even though the game was released in 2009, the graphics are great, texture quality is solid on 1080p, but character animations can be a bit stiff in some cases, mainly when fighting. For the 8 hours I've played, I encountered no bugs and the game crashed only once, on some occasions, if you die near the next checkpoint, you'll spawn there, but I don't think this is much of an issue.

All in all, it is a fantastic game and for €2 - it's an absolute steal. The story is quite good, graphics are good and there is stuff to do even after you complete the story. 

TL;DR 9/10

LO BUENO:
La fórmula que propone engancha desde el primer momento.
Realmente sientes que estás dentro de un juego de acción y consigue que entres en tensión durante las persecuciones, sin embargo en los momentos de más calma puede hacerte pensar en como moverte para pasar el nivel pero sin complicarte la vida demasiado.
Gráficamente es muy bueno para ser del 2009.
La animación de la campaña está muy bien hecha.
El doblaje al español es genial.
Es cortito, puedes completarlo en unas 7h y me parece más que correcto para que no acabe resultando pesado. La historia es poco profunda pero te mantiene en vilo hasta el final.

LO MALO:
Quiero destacar  que en ocasiones me parece impreciso a la hora de agarrarse a algún saliente mientras haces parkour, pero nada que deteriore la experiencia.
El FPS es flojo pero no es lo más importante del juego.

RECOMENDACIÓN:
Tienes que jugarlo. Propone un estilo de juego diferente vasado en el parkour con intensos momentos de escape al que también le añade FPS. Consigue ser adictivo y te enganchará en un par de tardes.

138712741.review:
MIRRORS EDGE: FIRST IMPRESSION

I had high hopes for this game, but I feel like this game has become more rage enducing than fun.

Janky mechanics and unclear instructions where to go. Everytime I´m about to "land safely" from a jump, I press shift, and I still take damage.
I remember getting stuck on one level because I could not even reach a pole, despite it´s showing it was the right way to go. I think I died more than five times on a level mainly because I was confused and did not know where to go.
I get it, this game is old. But thank god I only got this for like 2 dollars, if I had spent more I´d probably be more infuriated.
Half the challenge of this game is trying to find out where to go, sometimes dying several times because you didn't even know a jump was possible.
The controls are also janky as hell and I got crashed like three times, and I had to restart my PC.
And the brightness, jesus christ, even turning the brightness down all the way it´s still like you´re trying to play with the sun in your face.
It´s a shame really, this game has potential, but all this, just does not do it for me.

3/10

138624551.review:
Oh man, original Mirror's Edge... The game I felt in love with immediately back in the day. Everything about it is perfect - the unique and innovative gameplay, the immersion, the graphics, the art style, the soundtrack.

Such simple concept as "running" becomes nuanced and intricate the more you play the game. The player is not limited by arbitrary RPG elements, health bars, flying numbers over the UI or any other cancer elements of the modern games. There is just the view from your eyes, a few control buttons and the environment to traverse. The simplicity is refreshing, but it's also just a surface. There is a surprising depth in how you can use your surroundings to move around. By playing the game you will become more proficient and skilled in the running, getting experience without any experience points. That is such immersive aspect of the game that rarely any other game can deliver nowadays.

While the story is rather short, the levels are very well designed. The "runners vision" highlights pipes and springboards that you can use to casually run through, but there is always a shorter, more efficient and smarter way to cut the distance. Finding surprising paths and tricks you can do to beat time trials is akin solving the puzzle and is quite satisfying. The same goes for enemies, you can disarm them and start shooting from the SMG; you can run over the wall and smack the police in the face; or you can ignore the threat completely and do a (more challenging) no-harm walkthrough where you have to be fast - and smart on your pathing - to avoid the bullets.

Technically, the game stands out even today. Art direction, well baked lightning and colourful pallet make it hard to resist the desire to make screenshots of the city as you run. The PhysX is underrated and sadly forgotten technology that adds oomph to the scenes and makes the surroundings feel more alive. The shattering glass, transparent polyester materials that break from the bullets, the smoke from the pipes and particles of dust in the air that react to your movement ... it's not ray tracing, but it's better than some default Unreal Engine 4 effect that fades out from the screen in 1 second. And it's in 2008 game. Playing it now in high resolution with 144 FPS is just marvellous.

The soundtrack is a masterpiece from Solar Fields, it accompanies the game greatly and is one of those soundtracks that is great as a standalone album separate from the game. It adds that futuristic feeling in the calm puzzle scenes, as well as pumps up the drive when you are being chased.

With regards for the reboot (Mirror's Edge: Catalyst from 2017) - the first Mirror's Edge is not better or worse. It's just a different game, original implementation of the concept. Catalyst greatly improves fluidity of the movement, has fantastic graphics and soundtrack too, a big open world city that becomes your playground to explore, so I highly recommend it as well. Nevertheless, original Mirror's Edge stands on its own - one of the most unique and fun games ever released... Still alive.

I bought this game for one reason...to thumb it up!

This is my favourite game of all time. Works perfectly on the Steam Deck too.

I have purchased this for every platform I own, 360 on day one release, PS3, Origin now Steam.

Graphics wise this hasn't aged a single day, beautifully crafted and artistically styled.

Here's why I don't recommend this game:

[list]
[*] Performed extremely poorly out of nowhere after running just fine for an hour
[*] Not compatible with high frame rates. It'll break some of its physics.
[*] Game is actually sluggish despite having the aesthetic of speed. Movement is slow, mouse tracking is smoothed and acceleration can't be disabled.
[*] The game expects you to kind of find your way out of places by guessing where to go, and kills you for not figuring it out. There is an orientation button, but you won't like doing that while dudes are shooting you.

138561228.review:
Timeless classic! This is one of the few games that are simply a must-play. Criminally underrated title. When I was a kid, I was as blown away by this game's trailer on the same level as GTA V's. Other game that simply blew my mind at the time was Outlast. Few games are simply this good, G.O.A.T. in their respective genres (many created by the titles themselves).

I can't fit all of my thoughts about the game here but I very much agree with those videos and have felt the same after finishing the game. Credit to those people for making such in-depth videos due to their love for the game. This is the essence of "gaming", and what many modern titles are missing, with the people playing them also in turn missing what felt so special regarding their past releases.

Want to know more about the game while viewing a critique and analysis at the same time? If so, I HIGHLY suggest Whitelight's "Mirror's Edge: 13 Years Later" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7e_zNLyEReg and "Mirror's Edge | Retrospective - A Flawed Masterpiece https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_h5o9UVYmCE by GameTalesHQ on YouTube. SPOILER ALERT. Those are great videos!

The first playthrough is more messy and harder than it should be because there was a lack of details in the gameplay mechanics tutorial, mainly combat ones. Watch the "Gameplay" section on Whitelight's video to find how to take advantage of the game mechanics that they didn't tell you about. After that, it becomes easy.

VERY IMPORTANT!
My TIPS regarding fixing/avoiding the VERY few but major bugs this game has, which haven't been fixed (unsurprisingly) by EA:
I recommend fixing PhysX for NVIDIA users. If you don't do that, the game bugs out and becomes unplayable with PhysX in certain missions, making it impossible to go forward without either disabling or fixing it. Fix it in order to enjoy cool physics at basically no rendering cost. You can do that here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/17410/discussions/0/490123727976080324/

[!] ALSO: Avoid alt-tabbing at ALL COSTS. It freezes Windows big time. My only option when it happens is full-on rebooting. A possible fix for this bug is to run the game in a windowed program designed for full-screen games. I personally didn't and won't go through the hassle at the moment as I don't need to tab out, but you may find this helpful.


BTW, I made almost 400 screenshots throughout the game, because, as Whitlelight put it, this game's visuals are eye-candy and haven't aged one bit due to the DICE's innovation baking in the shadows and various effects, that are only now, after nearly 15 years, possible to be rendered in real-time. Feel free to check them out! Also, if you're interested about a more in-depth analysis on the game's visuals, I recommend "How Does Mirror's Edge Still Look This Good?" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2TNSaEJHBrQ&t by Jacob Geller on YouTube.



That's all! I hope you found this helpful.

138507573.review:
Very unique game, which I fondly remember. Running on rooftops, around (or in) skycrapers, minimalistic sterile white-red-orange enviroment is great, satisfying to play concept. It's sad that it didn't breed its own gender or proper series of videogames. 

Plot is pretty straightforward with some twist and build-ups. Interestingly cutscenes are a 2D animations, which may sound kinda lazy, but I personally never seen idea like this in games.

There are some shooting sections, different mission types able to keep your interest. Hardcore gamers and casual ones may find themself at home.

No perfomance issues, graphically still holds up.

It takes around 12 hours to do everything, buy it on sale tho.

When you press ALT the game shows you directions where to go by red smudge. Such small thing changed something and I search for such feature in other games. Also the game have immersive details like when you are told to "run fast" then you will be either complemented or yelled at - depending on how did you fullfilled your task. I played 2,5 year ago and I still remember all of these!

Sadly the game is very frustrating, like negative reviews point out. Many, many times I just couldn't grab the ledges! It straight up didn't work! I raged so much upon this. Especially with fact that I played sequel before this one and I see how greatly platforming has been improved later.

Despite this annoying flaw I recommend trying it out. It's a good, simple game which you can easily sink into.

138505493.review: Mirror's Edge is unlike any other game I've played and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys the occasional indie type game. To call Mirror's Edge an indie game, however, would not due this game justice. It only feels like it if you consider what the Studio of Mirror's Edge was working on at the time. In 2008 DICE was killing it with their grey-scale Battlefield games, so it came as a surprise to hear that they were working on a parkour game set in the near future teaming with only the most beautiful architecture and buildings. They took a risk, and after all these years I still feel that if payed off. The story is simple but still somehow full of enough heart that I was compelled to carry through each puzzle, the combat was choppy but the action sequences were few enough between that I actually looked forward to each encounter, and the the graphics were always incredible so I never feel like i'm playing an older game. Definitely give this game a try if you enjoy the catharsis of running away from an increasingly totalitarian government with the end goal of saving your sister and starting a spark of rebellion.

Mirror's Edge is one of my favorite games. I originally played it on PS3 and got 100% (all trophies), then I got it for free on PC (Origin) and kept playing it there, later completed it twice on my brother's Xbox Series S, and now I bought it on Steam to avoid EA's dumb launcher.

138419991.review:
Mirror's Edge is far from perfect, but there is a lot to love about it. On a visual and audio level, this game is gorgeous even by today's standards. The white city with brightly contrasted colors combined with the fantastic soundtrack and punchy sound effects is such a vibe. Movement feels (mostly) smooth and fluid, which makes the running feel amazing when you are maintaining your momentum through the rooftops.

However, there are some collision detection issues that can interrupt this flow and it's always frustrating when it happens. Gunplay feels very stilted and off too; which wouldn't be too bad if it was entirely avoidable, but there are multiple sections where taking out the people in your way is mandatory for progression and they kill the pacing of the game every time. Finally, the story is really short and not satisfying at all. There's a certain character who betrays you and you never get a final confrontation after the revelation, the ending comes out of nowhere, and nothing really feels resolved.

And yet I found myself able to look past all of the glaring faults and still enjoy the running for what it is. Mastering the movement of this game and finding a new height to view the city skyline from feels liberating and there's a certain rush that jumping across a massive rooftop gap gives which I have not felt in any other game. Despite its flaws, Mirror's Edge is a unique experience that is worth playing. I wish EA would give this franchise another chance, because it feels like a game that takes everything here and improves on it is within reach.

138370229.review:
(Not much to say right now, but will update later)

If you like (or enjoy the concept of) parkour, you will love this. It's very linear, but it's one of the best and more unique games I have ever played. It's made by DICE. If you've played any of the recent Battlefield games, you'll notice that they took ALL the parkour elements from this to make Catalyst (the sequel, and then implement all that into BF1 and BFV. It's a work of art.

With this original game there's some minor FOV issues, namely a lack of a proper FOV slider. There's a few easy fixes though. All it takes is a quick Google search, and only that's necessary if you're bothered by the slightly narrow FOV.

Audio, design, gameplay and style wise this game still holds up for a 2008 title.  It was incredibly well made and still is a fantastic game. If it it was released today as is (with minor technical changes) I think it would be a bestseller, especially with how popular freerunning/parkour is in games these days.

When Mirror's Edge (Original) released it didn't sell well. I guess it was too different. All the more reason to get it now, ESPECIALLY on sale. Get it RIGHT NOW.

[b]Addendum:[/b] Go look up Solar Fields on Spotify. He's responsible for [i]all[/i] the music in Mirror's Edge and Catalyst. You will love it.

138146724.review:
The parkour game that comes to mind when people talk about parkour games.

I love this game (And Catalyst despite the criticisms). The setting is interesting and the environment is pretty to look at, but the actual plot and dialog is meh. However that's not why you are here for... 

You run, you jump and put your acrobatic and pathfinding skills to the test. And you better not stop because 90% of the time people are shooting at you.

You can punch people, you can grab their guns and shoot their friends, but for me, the real satisfaction comes when you finish Hard Mode without using guns for the first time. Guns make combat 10 times easier yes, but they slow you down, prevent you from doing your acrobatics and generally break the flow. That's not why I play this game.

On that topic, the game is short. Your first time might take you between 5 to 6 hours, depending on how long you get stuck in the tricky parts and if you watch or skip cinematics. But once you learn it, it gets shorter and shorter. Now I run Hard mode pacifist in under 3 hours. 

But that's the thing, despite being short, it's a game that rewards mastery. It's not a game that loses it's charm when you know what lies ahead. Like racing games, once you know the road, it only gets better. Your second time will feel better than the first, and subsequent playthroughs give you the satisfaction of executing the maneuvers you need with more accuracy, and maybe the discovery of a new shortcut.

If you like racing, if you like parkour, and aren't intimidated by a challenge that is hard to master, you have to try this game.

138049464.review:
Mirror's Edge is one of the most criminally underrated and overlooked games ever made, by both the audience and EA itself

First played the game back on the Xbox 360 and absolutely loved it, saw the steam version on sale and now that I have a gaming rig with an Nvidia card (this game has some Nvidia exclusive Physx effects), wanted to see how it held up and replay via what I was hoping was the definitive version

If there is one thing ME excels at, its style and atmosphere. From the use of a largely gray/white color palette mixed with way oversaturated primary colors it has a unique style that is immediately striking. It also holds up well visually due to its reliance on style over detail and environments have a very clean and sterile look, something that also matches the theme and story of the game. The Physx effects looked pretty neat and were probably more impressive back at release but are used sparingly, like glass and cloth banners being destroyed by gunfire

Sound effects and music are both excellent and the soundtrack in particular really stands out, with a mix of ambient tracks to high intensity electronic stuff during chase and action scenes.

I played with both a controller and KBM, and find them equally fun to use. Controls are responsive and once you are moving quick and in the flow, all the parkour actions are satisfying to pull off. Each level in the game is essentially on big parkour puzzle where the name of the game is to avoid combat encounters and move as smoothly and quickly as you can from one area to the next. You can grab weapons and fight back but the shooting doesnt feel great and its not the point. Huge props to EA for making a big budget game like this where shooting was not the selling point, you can absolutely make it through without firing a bullet and as a matter of fact, its the recommended way. There are a handful of melee attacks you can use to subdue or get out of a bad situation and that is more than enough

The game is somewhat brief (I think I beat it in about 4-5 hours), but you could probably play longer if you care about picking up the runner bag collectibles, this version doesnt have achievements so I didnt bother. 

Really my only complaint with ME is the cheap looking and unappealing cinematics and the fact its over probably a little too soon. The game was remarkably fresh feeling and interesting back in '08 and outside of its sequel there really hasnt been anything else like it since, so it still is.

Highly recommended for anyone looking for a fun action game that breaks the mold of endless shooting. Enjoy the movement and soundtrack and this game should run on basically any PC at this point while still looking pretty sharp.

138023135.review:
Игра Mirror's Edge, разработанная компанией DICE и изданная Electronic Arts, представляет собой уникальный платформер от первого лица, который предлагает игроку стать частью группировки паркурщиков в футуристическом городе.

Достоинства:

1.Игровой процесс. Один из главных плюсов игры - это ее игровой процесс. Игрок должен прыгать, бегать, карабкаться и выполнять различные трюки, чтобы преодолеть препятствия и дойти до цели. Все это создает уникальный геймплей и делает игру захватывающей и интересной на протяжении всей игры.

2.Визуальный стиль. Mirror's Edge отличается оригинальным визуальным стилем. Белые стены города синхронно сочетаются с яркими цветами, что создает уникальную атмосферу, которую сложно найти в других играх.

3.Сюжет. Игра также имеет увлекательный сюжет. Главная героиня, Фейт, работает вместе с группировкой паркурщиков, которые борются с коррумпированным правительством. В ходе игры Фейт вынуждена сражаться со множеством врагов и решать различные головоломки, чтобы достичь своей цели.

4.Музыка. Один из основных элементов атмосферы игры - это музыка. Она помогает игроку полностью погрузиться в игровой мир и создает настроение, соответствующее сюжету игры.

Недостатки:

1.Короткая игровая кампания. Игровая кампания в Mirror's Edge довольно короткая и может быть пройдена за несколько часов. Это может быть разочаровывающим для игроков, которые ожидают длительного игрового опыта.

2.Отсутствие мультиплеера. В игре отсутствует многопользовательский режим, что может снизить интерес к игре у тех, кто ищет онлайн-соревнование.

3.Сложность. Mirror's Edge может быть довольно сложной для новичков в жанре, поскольку игра требует быстрой реакции и хорошей координации. Это может вызвать некоторые трудности в прохождении игры.

В целом, Mirror's Edge - это очень интересный экшен с необычным геймплеем и красивой графикой. Это игра для тех, кто ищет что-то новое и свежее в жанре шутеров. Но, как и в любой игре, есть свои недостатки, которые могут оказаться неприятными для некоторых игроков.

137659336.review:
A Timeless Gem with a Tarnished Edge


Mirror's Edge is a game that has always been held in high regard within the gaming community. As a first-person parkour adventure game released in 2008, it offered players a breath of fresh air with its unique gameplay mechanics and striking visual design. However, as we delve into the era of next-gen gaming, it's becoming increasingly apparent that this once-shining gem is starting to lose its luster.

First and foremost, let's acknowledge the aspects of Mirror's Edge that have made it so endearing to fans. The game's minimalist art style, combined with its vibrant color palette, made for a captivating experience that was distinct from any other game at the time. The innovative use of parkour as a core gameplay mechanic allowed players to experience a sense of freedom and fluidity that was unparalleled.

However, it's essential to recognize that Mirror's Edge has not aged as gracefully as one might hope. While the game's art style remains impressive, the graphics and overall visual fidelity are no longer up to par with modern standards. The once-fluid animations now appear clunky, and the textures can feel outdated, which may diminish immersion for new players.

The controls, although innovative for their time, can also feel unpolished and unresponsive at times. The precision and timing required for some parkour moves can lead to frustrating moments, especially when compared to the smoothness of more recent parkour-based games.

In conclusion, Mirror's Edge is a game that will forever be remembered for its pioneering gameplay and aesthetic qualities. It dared to be different and pushed the boundaries of what was possible in the gaming world. However, as we embrace the next generation of gaming technology, it's becoming increasingly clear that this once-revolutionary title is struggling to keep pace. Despite its shortcomings, Mirror's Edge is still a game worth experiencing, especially for those looking to explore the roots of modern parkour and action-adventure games.

After spending some time with Mirror's Edge, I have to say that the game didn't live up to my expectations. While the game's visual style is undoubtedly appealing, with its minimalistic and simple design, it doesn't make up for the game's many shortcomings.

The gameplay feels clunky and janky, which makes executing certain moves difficult, leading to frustrating gameplay experiences. As a parkour game, you'd expect to fall a lot, but the checkpoint system is excruciatingly terrible, often requiring you to replay long stretches of levels due to a single mistake. This quickly becomes tiresome, especially given the levels themselves are so repetitive and bland.

The game tries to introduce puzzle elements, but they feel more like chores than anything engaging or fun. They add little to the overall experience, which is a shame as the game could have used something to break up the monotony.

All in all, while Mirror's Edge has some strengths, including a unique visual style, it falls short in so many other areas. The gameplay is frustrating and the levels repetitive, making it difficult to stay engaged. The game's lack of variety and engaging content means I had to drop it.

1.5/5

137191908.review:
After almost 14 years of coming out on PC I had the time to play it, and I definitely recommend it.

Mirror's Edge is a game that truly pushes the boundaries of what a first-person action game can achieve. Released on PC in 2009, it was praised for its immersive atmosphere, vast vertical and horizontal spaces, fluid game dynamics, and natural camera mechanics that follow the character's movements.

One of the standout features of Mirror's Edge is its unique art style, which creates a clean and minimalist world with vibrant colors that make the game world feel alive. The game's visual design also includes some truly breathtaking environments that range from soaring skyscrapers to the gritty underbelly of the city, all of which are brought to life with impressive attention to detail.

The gameplay in Mirror's Edge is equally impressive, with a focus on free-running and parkour-style movement that allows players to navigate their environment in exciting and fluid ways. The game's control scheme is intuitive and easy to pick up, but mastering the various moves and techniques takes skill and practice. The level design is also top-notch, offering a wide range of challenges that require both quick reflexes and strategic thinking.

The camera mechanics in Mirror's Edge are also noteworthy, as they add to the game's immersive feel by following the character's movements in a natural way that makes the player feel like they are truly a part of the action. Whether running along walls, sliding under obstacles, or leaping across chasms, the camera always manages to keep up with the player, providing a seamless and immersive experience.

Overall, Mirror's Edge is an outstanding game that deserves all the praise it has received. From its immersive atmosphere and stunning visual design to its fluid gameplay and natural camera mechanics, it is a game that truly pushes the boundaries of what a first-person action game can achieve. If you're looking for a thrilling and immersive gaming experience, look no further than Mirror's Edge.

137052489.review:
Mirror's Edge is a game that takes the concept of parkour and turns it into a thrilling and immersive experience. The premise of the game was incredibly unique when it first released and it's still a standout title in the gaming industry. The smooth and fluid animations of the protagonist Faith make you feel like you're truly running and jumping across rooftops in a dystopian world.

One of the biggest strengths of Mirror's Edge is its commitment to its core gameplay mechanics. The game focuses on parkour and running, and it executes those elements so well that it's hard not to get caught up in the momentum of it all. The bright and colorful visuals, coupled with the fast-paced action, make Mirror's Edge a game that's impossible to put down.

The story is another strong point of Mirror's Edge. It's a well-crafted tale of a world in which personal freedom is being stifled and the government is watching your every move. Faith is a likable and relatable protagonist who's easy to root for, and her interactions with the other characters help to flesh out the world and make it feel more real.

However, one aspect of the game that can be jarring is the use of animated cutscenes. While the game's graphics are stunningly realistic (for the time), the cutscenes have a distinct anime style that can take some getting used to. Nonetheless, this does not detract from the overall enjoyment of the game.

136878294.review:
A gentle classic that holds up incredibly well and shines as a great showcase of strong art direction and focused technical competence elevating a barebones 6-hour game into a gem that stands the test of time. Even if an imperfect marriage of the first-person perspective and parkour mechanics may leave you scratching your head at jarring dips in pacing for what is clearly meant to be an elegant ride - primarily due to bad tutorialization and era-specific level streaming bottlenecks - the meticulously sharp artstyle is ever the safety net, even in those situations. 

The cleanliness of the cityscape is an almost bizarrely abstract dance of whites and blues with contextual accents of red marking your unfolding path, often juxtaposed against bold interior levels where suddenly the balance inverts and primary colors take center stage. But the minimalism in shape and palette is itself a red herring, as material textures and design are the secret stars of the show; for as often you find yourself missing a ledge, doing an imperfect wallrun, or clambering up the millionth red pipe, you still get to appreciate just how polished the material bumpmaps are in every little corner of the world and down to point-blank range. The same can't be said of character models, but it feels like an appropriate compromise here; like I mentioned above, this is a focused shot of technical competence in areas that shine brightest. It feels almost bravely indie in that regard.

To that end, the length may seem short, but even that ultimately feels like a welcome breath of fresh air. Cool as it might look from the side, kinetic first-person platforming puzzles with crudely bolted-on hand-to-hand combat are not the densely rich gameplay loops you want overstaying their welcome. It's a tight, linear run through increasingly varied concrete mazes with stark color profiles that test your reflexes and spacial awareness, and terminate just as the headspinning gets a little annoying. With nothing but a flimsy plot of cliches holding the rest of it together, it can be a visually pleasant spectacle for an evening or two before moving on to other games.

136575784.review:
Un hito en la historia de los videojuegos que inauguró el género del parkour en el ámbito, una apuesta peligrosa en su momento y sobre todo un juego que si bien enamoró a pocos, lo hizo con todo el alma. Dentro reseña!

No sé cuántos años hacía ya desde que jugué por última vez en mi PS3, Mirror's Edge fue una propuesta arriesgada por parte de EA, algo diferente a lo que nos tenía acostumbrado la compañía y fue una idea muy original.

Nos ponemos en la piel de Faith, una runner que deberá correr por su vida en una ciudad en la que la información es todo. Y es que entre capítulos tendremos una cinemáticas modo cómic contando la historia además de escenas in game en diferentes situaciones.

El gameplay se basa en el parkour, correr, saltar, trepar por paredes, giros rápidos, agarcharse, sumado a un combate (en escasas situaciones) con varios combos de parkour e incluso se atreve a convertirse en shooter de vez en cuando, toda la experiencia en primera persona. Por lo cual si te mareas con los juegos de acción en primera persona y odias el cabeceo constante del personaje directamente ni lo juegues. Los escenarios son variados, encontrando horizontales y verticales, interiores y exteriores, pese a que el aspecto de la ciudad sea igual. Podemos hacer el camino (si bien parece un mundo abierto, no lo es) por diferentes lados y saltos, pudiendo encontrar incluso coleccionables (30). No podemos personalizar a Faith. La música está bien sin destacar. No empatizaremos con los personajes pues no tienen profundidad alguna. Y la historia si bien rebuscada, nada del otro mundo. Pero el concepto, el mundo que plantea, el parkour constante (sin otros aditivos) y los escenarios son únicos. 

Contaremos con un botón guía para no perdernos y la visión de runner (que podremos desactivar a nuestro antojo) harán algo más fácil. La dificultad (fácil y normal) solo repercute al combate y cómo de esponja somos con las balas. No afecta al parkour por lo que recomiendo disfrutarlo en fácil. Post game no existe, podremos rejugar los capítulos que queramos. Había una tabla de clasificaciones online a modo de multijugador que no sé si sigue existiendo.

El port a steam, 60fps en 1080 es una maravilla, sin caídas, va como un tiro, sabiendo que la última vez lo jugué en PS3 podéis imaginar. Encima no tiene el launcher de EA/Origin, así que es una compra asegurada. El juego puede durarte unas 4-5 horas y hay checkpoints.

Acompaña a Faith en una ciudad infestada de poder e información, donde el más rápido se hace con todo. Gracias por leer! <3

136098037.review:
"You can't live on the edge all your life, Faith. Sooner or later, you'll have to jump!" - Jackknife to Faith
This game invokes my fear of falling (basophobia) when I missed a step during parkour. (Luckily it faded into black and restarts at checkpoint). It captures the thrills of running away from enemies, has animated cut scenes, challenging yet intuitive control, saving someone you love no matter the cost with authentic music and clean graphics.

Graphics: can run on potato PC (no stutter on both Intel i3-1005g1 internal UHD graphics and AMD Ryzen 3600 + Nvidia GTX 1650 super)
Music: Excellent, with ending theme is soothing and pleasant.
Keyboard or controller: Keyboard preferred
Pros: Clean linear levels, parkour mechanism, animated cut scenes, cyberpunk setting, no EA/Origin launcher needed.
Cons: No HUD on amount of bullets when picked up guns, less fluid in gun fight, no manual save point, multiplayer server has been shut down
Get it when... on sale! Do check out on Mirror Edge Catalyst for retelling of story with better upgrades (for example mag rope as grappling shot) and easier controls.

135590475.review: Mirror’s Edge is a game that admittedly feels dated since it came out in 2008. Even though the age of the game is definitely notable, the raw gameplay of running and jumping around feels very fun. The art direction of the game is unique as the city that you jump around is mostly white mixed with another bright color depending on the section of the game, which might not be appealing to everyone, but I enjoy it for what it is. A couple of negatives I would give is that the combat is not very good, and it feels much better to run away and evade enemies than be forced to fight them like in certain sections of the game. Another negative is that sometimes it can be easy to get lost when you don’t know exactly where you need to go and that can lead to aimlessly running around trying to figure out what to do, which can be very frustrating. All in all, though I think Mirror’s Edge is still a very fun, short game that’s worth checking out if it’s on sale.

135124345.review:
Several reasons to play in Mirror's Edge:

It's a great workout for your fingers! You'll be hitting those buttons so fast, you'll burn off all those extra calories you gained from your last snack.

It's a great way to practice your parkour skills without actually having to leave your house! Just make sure you don't accidentally jump off your couch while playing.

Mirror's Edge is the perfect game for people who love to break things - you get to smash through glass windows and knock down doors without actually causing any real damage.

The game's stunning graphics and immersive world will make you feel like you're really there - which is great, because let's face it, who wouldn't want to run across rooftops and leap across huge gaps in real life?

The game's music is so awesome, you'll want to turn it up and dance along as you play. Just be careful not to bump into anything!

It's a great stress reliever! There's nothing like running and jumping around a dystopian city to forget about all your real-life problems.

The game's protagonist, Faith, is a total badass. Playing as her is empowering and inspiring, and you'll feel like you can take on the world after playing.

Mirror's Edge is the perfect game to play with friends - you can take turns trying to beat each other's high scores, and you'll all have a great time laughing at each other's mistakes.

You'll get to experience the thrill of being chased by the police without actually breaking any laws! It's the best of both worlds.

And finally, playing Mirror's Edge will make you cooler than all your friends who haven't played it yet. So what are you waiting for? Get playing!

134773976.review:
[b]TL;DR[/b] - grab this on sale if you like parkour and creative mechanics, but don't expect to be gripped by the story or spend more than 15 hours or so in the game unless you are into speedruns.

This is tricky. If it was the year of release, I would absolutely recommend this without question. The concept and mechanics were innovative. The art style was unique. By today's standards, however, I don't feel it holds up well, despite the parkour and movement mechanics.

For a sale, I'd certainly pick it up and play it through on an easy mode to enjoy the parkour mechanics. First person parkour makes it more enjoyable than, say, Assassin's Creed, Tomb Raider, or Uncharted games.

The story and music are pleasant if you are into late 2000s nostalgia, which I am, so it was nice, but not a story that would draw you in at all. It was predictable and I was not invested in it at all; it felt like a means to connect different levels together for creative parkour and map scaling challenges, not the other way around, where you [i]want[/i] to platform in order to see what's next.

Graphically, the basic art style helps in maintaining a reasonable standard in today's age, and it is creative in simplicity and minimalism. That being said, it gets boring after the first half or so of the story where you progress from white room with blue chairs to white room with green chairs and white room with orange chairs, glancing around for whatever is red to help you out (if that assist is turned on).

If it didn't take me several years of picking it up saying "you know what, now is the time to finish this game" to finish it, I would recommend it. In truth, [b]it felt like more of a chore by the end than a joy, despite the innovative mechanics of the time[/b], and [i]that[/i] may be more insightful to [i]my own state[/i] than the game itself.

132276064.review:
I don't think I've ever loved such a flawed game so much. 
Yes, the story is a little boring, and yes, the combat encounters can be a little infuriating, but the biggest flaw I can think of is that it's a bit too short for its own good.
Despite being over a decade old at this point, there's really nothing quite like Mirror's Edge, meaning that the general gameplay of split-second pathfinding decisions and surveys of the space around you is something that most people need some time to get a feel for, and a 6-hour story mode just isn't going to cut it.
However, when you DO take the time to really understand the movement (and yes, even the combat), believe me when I say that Mirror's Edge is one of the most blissful gaming experiences you'll ever have. If you think it's worth the frustration (I certainly do), give this a try for sure.
Oh, and a side note: everything about the visual and auditory presentation is phenomenal. The art design and use of lighting absolutely curbstomps 99% of AAA games releasing today, and the sound design with its focus on wind and Faith's breathing work wonders to sell the sense of breathtaking speed. The score by Solar Fields is also an all-timer.

Mirror's Edge is a good game. I enjoyed it. It has outstanding visual style, an amazing world, and it was a trailblazer for parkour games. I wouild recommend others to play it. 

I will unashamedly say, however, that the game is starting to show its age. The FOV, which is locked at 60 or something unless you go and edit config files, can be sickening. The menus can be a bit quirky to navigate. And while the art style is timeless, the aged textures look increasingly blurry in the modern day. I would like a remaster personally, and would unashamedly drop some cash on one. 

But... it doesn't make the game objectively worse or something. Back in 2009, this was no doubt the creme de la creme. I just think it deserves a refresh.

I thoroughly enjoyed the game. It was challenging enough to be engaging, with well placed breaks to take a breath and prepare for the next rush through a shootout. Calmer parts were still just engaging. The combat situations were not repetitive and different tactics were needed in different scenarios, which I appreciate. The story was not exactly ground breaking, but it was ultimately not the driving force of the game. It was good enough that I cared to follow it. The graphics hold up surprisingly well, the game still looks great and stylish after over a decade. 
My complaints are minor. There were some cases where objects that would be easy to climb in real life (for someone with the character's skills or close) were not climbable at all.
At the end of the day I'm perfectly happy with the time I spent playing and replaying it. It's a good game.

131331133.review:
Widely popular game, but so far had a terrible time with it. It is the type of game where the objective seems to enter a flow state and feel like a powerful parkour runner, but the game seemingly does everything to break that immersion. I do understand that most people might not have these issues, but I can't recommend it in good conscience:    
For a game from 2009, it runs terribly on my steamdeck. Even with low settings at 720p my fps drop to five when there are enemies close to me.  In other scenes, I can keep my steady 60. 
In theory, the art style is unique and appealing. In practice (I am playing on a projector) the whites contrast is so low, that between entering buildings or vents and going outside again, I have to enter the options and crank the brightness to either the maximum or minimum in order to see.  
Some levels feel more like riddles to me, where I fall or get shot over and over again, until I figure out that I missed a button the entire time or I that there is a hanging plattform over the hole that sinks when you enter it from a specific side.

The story is also the most boring and predictable cyberpunk conspiracy ever

130773252.review:
This is a great game, so unique and fresh, even in 2022. 
Mirror’s Edge was a bit of an experiment for EA, to see if gamers would appreciate something a little different than the string of first person shooters that were flooding the market back then. They didn’t. The sales figures disappointed EA and when we eventually did get a sequel it had lost many of the things that made this game so unique to begin with.
Mirror’s Edge is a bit of a cult favorite these days and for good reason. I don’t know if you’ll like it, but I sure as heck do. The world you’ll inhabit is a very clean, very ordered retro future where the populace have traded disorder, uncertainty, and crime for a society that’s controlled by the corpo’s. Information is repressed and individuality is discouraged. And for the most part, it seems to work. The world seems better than the one we live in today. There are some that resist this corporate utopia however, and you’ll play as one of these malcontents in the game. She’s a young woman called Faith. These dissidents call themselves runners. They’re basically couriers who smuggle illegal and highly sensitive data by running across rooftops to avoid the persuasive CCTV cameras that litter the streets below. You do all of this in first person, while trying your best to avoid confrontation with the authorities since they are armed and you are not. It’s all about evasion rather than confrontation, parkour instead of slaughter. Still interested? Give it a go! 

10/10

130106710.review:
Mirror's Edge is pretty damn cool. I used to play this game as a kid on my older computer since it's really well optimized but I never played more than the first few levels. Now, I finally finished it and it was fun.

The world design, atmosphere and look of the game is incredible. The game is 15 years old but it still looks pretty because of the great use of colors. Runner Vision is really cool and very helpful during chases. The gameplay is mostly smooth. Parkour is phenomenal and you can't really find anything better, even after all these years. It can be clunky here and there, especially in smaller areas but it's generally great. There are a few platforming puzzles where you have to find an exit in a tight space and it's really rewarding to do so. Regarding melee, I think I didn't grasp it quite well. It definitely felt like I was missing something since everything I knew was attack and counter. It was fine enough though, and it helped me acquire weapons to clear out the rest of the enemies if necessary. The gunplay is fine, it's not that fun but it's very useful.

A few drawbacks would be the story, characters and voice acting. I really didn't follow the story nor did I remember who is who except a few people. They're generally forgettable but it's fine since the focus is on the gameplay. [spoiler] The Celeste fight was really wonky and weird. I really thought I wasn't doing it properly but oh well. [/spoiler] The ending is underwhelming too. The game is also quite short which is a shame, but then again, you could really feel they didn't have too many ideas left gameplay-wise.

All in all, 8/10. I recommend buying it on sale.

129771828.review:
Reseña de Mirror's Edge jugado en Steam Deck:

Elegantísimo y original (en su día) juego de tipo "parkour", donde encarnamos a una "runner" que se ve envuelta en una trama que es una mera excusa para ir escapando fase a fase por diferentes escenarios a modo de puzzle arcade de plataformas en fps.

El juego resulta muy entretenido y a nivel de diseño es estupendo. Correr, deslizarse, saltar, buscar escapatorias imposibles es muy diver y en todo momento me incita a seguir buscando una salida para ver el siguiente nivel. El que vaya buscando un juego tipo fps se va a ver defraudado, porque precisamente esa parte de pelear está implementada de manera un poco regulera (de hecho en algún momento es bastante molesto porque no te queda otra que pelear, y el juego no va de eso).

A nivel gráfico a pesar de ser un juego antiguo tiene tal clase que aguanta fenomenal el tipo, con esa estética futurista de ciudad impoluta. El sonido está bien aunque la ost no destaca (la última canción mola y ya).

Como pega más grande, aparte de esa parte de pelear, en mi opinión el juego es excesivamente corto (menos de 10 horas me ha llevado) y aunque tiene el planteamiento de poder hacer speedruns de las fases superadas, a mí no me ha llamado tanto la atención como para ponerme con ello (me gustaba más el hecho de tener que pensar en el "combo de movimientos" para buscar el camino).

En la Deck obviamente va sobradísimo. Ni se inmuta el cacharro, y lo único que requiere es un tiempo inicial para adaptarse a los controles con el mando (no es fácil, tuve que probar varias configuraciones hasta que encontré una que personalicé para estar cómodo).

Nota final: Recomendado. La verdad es que me ha defraudad un poquito. Lo jugué hace ochocientos años y tenía un recuerdo buenísimo, pero al rejugarlo no creo que sea ese juego de culto sino sencillamente un buen juego.

129600290.review:
Not recommended unless you play free with EA Play.

The physics engine + level design didn't age well on this one, if they were ever 100%. There's lots of specific spots where you pretty much just have to keep trying again and again until the physics interaction just *works*. (I.e. try ad nauseum until the character grabs the ledge, or the jump after the wall run actually works, the mob gets disarmed, etc etc etc). At the beginning of the game, the difficulty is easy so you can mostly breeze past this stuff, but by the end things ramp up and the jank in the physics engine really starts to break down the game play. There was one specific jump in the 2nd last level I spent over half an hour repeating until it finally worked. Didn't even feel like a skill issue by the time I got it... the physics interaction just eventually registered. Also, I'll put in one last mention that while the game is decent at checkpointing, sometimes you're just stuck repeating a long segment just to be able to retry a buggy jump.

I played on normal (only easy / normal are available until you beat the game), and I liked how it felt like the regular mobs were challenging. Knowing that any particular NPC can delete you keeps you on your toes. I also liked and disliked how the level design doesn't handhold you in many spots. Sometimes you're just left running around scrambling to find a way through. It can be frustrating in a way, but maybe the game's biggest success is capturing that tense feeling of being on the run.

If the parkour flow wasn't broken all the time by the jank in the physics engine, I could see paying a few bucks for this on sale. Maybe this was a great title back in the day, on an older O/S with different drivers. But as it is, today, I can only recommend just giving it a once once through on the EA Play pass, maybe.

128453865.review:
This game is pretty great. One moment you're chilling, hopping across rooftops, climbing through vents - next thing you know, a chopper and like five dudes with machine guns and sniper rifles are on your tail. You sprint between walls, hurriedly climb over fences, split second decisions left and right, and when you've barely escaped within an inch of your life, the game showers you in this immense relief of 'holy shit, how did I get away with that'

It is exactly what it says on the tin - think Minecraft parkour but with less tedious and much more satisfying movement. At times, the movement can feel like you're just trying to hit a quick-time event over and over again, but mostly it strikes this lovely balance between [i]speed[/i] and [i]weight[/i] that feels very fulfilling. The other game design elements really compliment it in this regard. The police feel like an actual force to be reckoned with, and the 'fight or flight' part of it really helps pump up your adrenaline. The level design is intuitively crafted, so you always instinctively know [i]where[/i] to go, but never exactly [i]how[/i] to get there. And lastly, the OST in this game is super well done - it subtly nudges you into this edge of your seat urgency, while never drawing so much attention to itself as to impact your immersion.

Now, there are times when these elements fail to do their part. They largely rely on eachother to be 'convincing' - so if e.g. the level design fails at some points, and a row of jumps become just a bit too annoying, the whole illusion of urgency falls apart. I had this happen a few times, and I wouldn't say it impacted my experience very much, but it did show that the game doesn't have the polish it could've had.

I'd also just like to comment on the gun-play - if you're looking for the 'movement shooter' experience in a single player game, this really isn't it. I personally loved the combat in this game - picking up a gun really felt like you weren't a trained shooter (because the MC truly is [i]just[/i] good at running)... which meant you'd get a gun, dump the [i]entire magazine[/i] into some poor unsuspecting cop, then quickly sprint away - which felt really appropriate! 

Overall though, this game is just great. It's a series of some of the highest of highs in terms of stress and adrenaline, and some of the most satisfying, relaxed lows I've seen in a game in a long time, and the game has nearly perfected finding a fun balance between the two.

8/10, must-buy when on sale.

128307641.review:
"In positive psychology, a flow state, also known colloquially as being in the zone, is the mental state in which a person performing some activity is fully immersed in a feeling of energised focus, full involvement, and enjoyment in the process of the activity. In essence, flow is characterised by the complete absorption in what one does, and a resulting transformation in one's sense of time."

At first, you will suck. You will suck bad. But keep pushing through and you'll find beneath the surface-level appeal—Solar Fields' beautiful cyberpunk/ambient soundtrack, the iconic art design, unparalleled atmosphere—lies an incredibly deep game with endless replayability and a nauseatingly-high skill ceiling. It's not for everyone; but for those who vibe, Mirror's Edge is the gift that keeps on giving.

But the main issue for me personally was the way this game ended leaving a sour taste in my mouth knowing there's no continuation with the revolution to be satisfied with and that's kind of sad for me. 

Despite the graphic being dated and the low resolution, it is still aesthetically pleasing to the eyes with the red and white colour palette and polygon model covering many landscapes and buildings to run, climb and hop over that making the whole experience a chilling one.

127956444.review: I was still young when this game first came out. While it obviously made a very strong positive impression on me, and was one of the first games I really got into that wasn’t just a licensed game (no shade on Star Wars Battlefront), I couldn’t really appreciate what was in front of me the way I do now. In the middle of their mid-aughts decline, EA just decided to let DICE hammer out a focused, polished AA game designed both around a strong linear story and the idea of speedrunning. Even if they had to include guns, its clearly treated as a ridiculous element. The hyper-clean Y2K aesthetics of the city, the primacy of level design over “realism,” the completely one of a kind look and feel of it all- this seems like it should be a recent indie darling, but it was the result of DICE briefly escaping from the Battlefield mines, and it came out over 12 years ago. Given all of this, I shouldn’t be surprised that Catalyst ended up being so disappointing for so many, but I can’t be mad about it either. Sometimes a miracle can’t happen twice.

126721995.review:
The main draw of Mirror's Edge is by far the graphics & art direction, even though it was released in 2009 the game still looks absolutely gorgeous and beats most games being released today.

The gameplay is solid as well, an entire playthrough took me 6 hours which is completely fine for such a fast paced game - it doesn't overstay its welcome. My main concern was that this would be one of those "stand here + press this" types of games, seeing as this is how parkour is most commonly done, however I was pleasantly surprised by how unrestricted it is; 9/10 times if it resembles a wall, railing or ledge you can climb it!

The 1 thing that prevents ME from being perfect is the combat. Though admittedly it's well balanced (you can steal weapons by parrying enemies and the stronger the weapon, the slower you move), I just don't want to play a shooter here, I'd rather jump about for 100% of the time. 

I'll definitely be doing another playthrough soon

The nostalgia definitely goes hard for this game, but it holds up incredibly well in 2022. The graphics are crisp and clean, and the minimalist style is beautiful. The feeling of the parkour is excellent, you can feel the momentum, and it really makes movement and combining different moves intuitive.

It's not perfect of course, the story is barebones and the combat is pretty basic and often breaks the pacing of a level, and the animated cutscenes don't really do it for me. But overall, this is an amazing game that I think everyone should give a try. Few games offer a parkour experience like this one.

124247159.review:
wtl;dr Mirror's Edge is a classic, buy it now. This game rules.

Maybe pedantic nerds would consider Mirror's Edge an FPS, but really it's a platformer—a game about clearing obstacles as elegantly and efficiently as you can. The distinction is extremely important, for reasons I'll get into. And man, does its movement hold up. Running, jumping, sliding, wall-hopping, pipe-climbing, ziplining—this game has it all, and each mechanic is executed to perfection. Rarely does movement in a game feel so distinctive yet natural.

The story concerns the adventures of a young woman called Faith, one of a group of underground couriers called (what else?) Runners. Together they deliver goods and information around a beautiful, ultramodern City where life is comfortable and there's almost no crime—because of an oppressive regime with tight control over its citizens. Faith has a sister, Kate, who is more straight-laced. (She works as a cop.) The game starts when insurgent mayoral candidate Robert Pope is assassinated and Kate is framed for his murder.

Beat-for-beat, the story of Mirror's Edge is essentially an action film. Even my biased ass can't identify some sleeper genius writing decision that makes it remarkable. The perfect gameplay makes it satisfying, sure, but a lot of action games have great gameplay. That's kind of the point. And yet...the experience of playing through the game has stuck with me all these years in a way no comparable title really has.

I think it's the effectiveness with which you're put into Faith's perspective. You have her skill at running, and her physical limitations. You hear her grunt with effort when she climbs and pant when she sprints. The complexity with which you move through the environment of the City makes it memorable, makes it a character, even in spite of its pristine, sterile aesthetic.

Or maybe because of it? Early on, it's revealed that Faith and Kate's parents were killed in brutal crackdowns that were a response to protests against power grabs by the City's leadership. The game takes place long after they're gone—long after they lost. The City is beautiful now, sleek, elegant, tourist-friendly, soulless. The game's theme, [i]Still Alive[/i] (not that one), is addressed to the City. "I know there's something wrong," it says. "Your concrete heart isn't beating." Faith's feet pound against a home that's dying with each step.

That's why Mirror's Edge is not an FPS. You can't shoot your way out of gentrification. You can't take an AR-15 to "development", wealth inequality, displacement. What magazine, what bullet cartridge, kills exploitation itself? No, Faith is no one-woman army. She crumples at bullets, especially on hardmode, and can't even run with many of the weapons she picks up, rendering them useless except as a momentary last resort. This game is not about [i]overcoming[/i] the villain, [i]destroying[/i] them with superior firepower. It's about running, escaping, surviving another day. That's what makes it so affecting.

Mirror's Edge was lightning in a bottle. Flawless gameplay, unforgettable setting, and a perfect length. Faith Connors will forever be one of gaming's most iconic action heroes, a title well-deserved. If for some unfathomable reason you're still reading this rambling nonsense, stop and buy it already. You will not regret it.

P.S. Don't bother with the sequel.

123450353.review:
Mirror's Edge reminds me of looking out of the window of an aeroplane. It's breathtakingly beautiful and gives me that same feeling in my stomach as when the plane takes off and lands.

The visuals are incredibly cool. In particular, the sweeping skylines and use of bold colours give it a look that is distinctively Mirror's Edge.

The music is excellent. The ambient tracks in each of the locations are great at setting the mood, but my favourite song is Still Alive from the end credits.

The game's biggest problem is the frequency of the fights, especially because it doesn't seem to want to be a fighting game. When a game looks the way Mirror's Edge does, you want to spend more time exploring the environments instead of being rushed through the levels. It also makes the game more difficult to play. If some of the moves are challenging for the player, it's considerably harder to take the time to master them when the game is putting pressure on you to hurry. You can fail a level for not being quick enough or by being shot to death by enemies.

Mirror's Edge would have benefitted from developing its story and characters. I would have liked to understand the political climate better and to have got to know the people in Faith's life better. But there is enough there to more or less understand Faith's goals and motivations.

This game's flaws are significant yet I still enthusiastically recommend Mirror's Edge.

Mirror's Edge 1 is the same game that I remember from the Xbox 360. Surprisingly good graphics, fun movement gameplay, and simple and intuitive controls. The PC port is actually very good, maintaining great performance on a lower end machine without any noticeable impact visually - I don't even recall if I touched graphics settings. Controls were fine.

The major downfalls of ME1 are the same as ever - the game is woefully short for how fun it is, and later levels branch out into mechanics that aren't fun or leave the actual fun ones behind. The visual design is impeccable, the tension and action and music are great, the story is simple and doesn't try to do more than what it needs to. If only the game were longer, and had some more levels. 20$ for 4 hours of your life isn't bad, but maybe get it on a sale.
