122305703.review:
A short but sweet game about running around a fictional city plagued by corrupt politicians operating a surveillance state that manages to feel quite real. Once you get used to the controls the game is good fun. I recommend binding the "show me the way" key to a side mouse button or something similar as the game falls back on it in a few sections. The plot reminds me of some kind of crime thriller you'd watch on cable TV, which is refreshing when a lot of games have you battling god itself by the end of them. Overall there isn't much here but what is here is quite good. I'd say Mirror's Edge manages to exist in that sweet zone of being greater than the sum of its parts. 

If you want, you can get a month of EA Play for 5 USD and crank this game out in a day or two, leaving you plenty of time to enjoy the rest of the catalog.

122127087.review: If I can describe a game as "cool", this would be it.  I love how stylized this game is.  Everything about it is so fluid and slick, from the movements to the fast pacing to the parkour and fighting.  This game does not wait for you and it is unforgiving, forcing you to make split second decisions on how to evade the oncoming barrage of gunfire and enemies.  The way you move and look around and interact with the environment around you makes it feel you really are doing all these wall jumps and rolls and punches.  With that and the fact that you can literally hear your character breathing, it really feels like you are controlling a living breathing person.  The various ways to get to that vent or platform or getting around enemies/obstacles is enough for multiple replays.  Your environment is a puzzle to get through.  Add that futuristic aesthetic and music, it's a winner for me.  The only things I'm slightly iffy about are the occasional bugs and animations for the cut-scenes, I like the art but I do feel like the change in art styles do break the flow of the game a little.  The story isn't anything mind-blowing but it's easy to follow and certainly interesting enough to keep you glued to what's happening.  In my opinion none of these things hinder the experience at all.  So ambitious for its time and will always hold up.  I fell in love with it immediately and I'm definitely gonna do a replay.  Can't recommend enough.  9/10

122096962.review:
This game is quite successful in its main appeal but falls flat in its recursive attempts to engage you in its extraneous gameplay.

The Good

- Being chased and shot at feels really good, especially in the early levels. It feels quite tactile and exciting!
- The OST makes the aforementioned chases feel awesome!
- Visually pleasing artistic direction that has aged pretty well for a 2009 game.

The Bad

- It feels like I am always battling to figure out where I am supposed to be going in spite of there being a button dedicated to telling you where to go This is especially prevalent in slower segments. There are frequent moments in which the end destination is clearly visible, but the way to get to it is convoluted. 
- Pretty hit or miss level design overall. You cannot jump or climb on many surfaces you'd think you could, jump distance/height can be ambiguous, visual clutter can get in the way, etc. The levels are not very intuitive.
- Combat is REALLY bad. You are simultaneously having to mash for your life and watching for a (VERY TIGHT) parry window. Feels like the best means of fighting the clunky AI is to not fight them at all.

Each of these bad points works together to disrupt the flow of the game. There are too many times where I am not engaged in the exciting, blood-pumping parkour/chasing this game was designed for, and I am instead dying repeatedly (to what I would call unfair situations) or lost as to where I am supposed to go.

Okay, yes, I finished it in less than an hour on normal mode, skipping through most of the cutscenes. 
This time at least. This was my 6th playthrough of Mirror's Edge, so maybe that puts things into perspective.
I absolutely adore this game, it still has me hooked to the story and gameplay every time I boot it up, literally right from the intro (you know the one I'm talking about). The game is 13 years old, but the graphics hold up to this day in my opinion, mostly because the biggest focus is on the architecture, and making you really feel as if you own the rooftops, despite being only a teeny little human.
Of course the gameplay and combat have some flaws, but it's mostly in the sense that it lacks variety, and I don't really blame a 13 year old game where the main objective is "parkour" for that. Still, it would be fun if the game where you're supposed to pick off enemies one at a time, or maybe even avoid combat as best as you can, to have some more varied combat moves. 
Other than that, superb soundtrack, great voice acting, great worldbuilding, the works.

121550029.review:
[h1]Comentario Analítico: "Mirror's Edge"[/h1]

Excelente videojuego de parkour en primera persona, manejar a Faith Connors es tan sencillo como satisfactorio y difícilmente te vas a encontrar atorado en una sección, el juego se las arregla para guiarte por su mundo haciendo uso de colores llamativos entre tan exagerada iluminación.

Mecánicamente es relativamente sencillo pero lo suficientemente bien diseñado como para no aburrir ni, por el contrario, abrumar.

Su atmósfera destaca por lo blanco y limpio, y se condice con su música (Excelente el track "Still Alive" interpretado por Lisa Miskovsky), sin embargo un aspecto con el que choca de cara es su argumento. 

El régimen totalitario del que se nos habla sólo hace presencia en las cinemáticas animadas, pero cuando toca jugar encontramos mapas limpios y carentes de algún indicio de lo que el argumento nos quiere decir. Sé que hay un comic que se explaya un poco más en todo esto, pero por ahora no lo leí y en el juego per se hay temas como el de las protestas o la madre de Faith que carecen de peso pese a estar tan presentes. 

Pero si dejamos de lado estos conflictos u otros como el pedante tutorial, el caótico control de las armas de fuego o el sistema anti-piratería (Que está tan mal implementado que puede llegar a ocurrir con la versión original), nos vamos a encontrar con un buen juego.

Divertido, frenético y sencillo de manejar. Quizá sus controles no hayan envejecido tan bien, habiendo a día de hoy juegos de parkour más elaborados, pero visto en contexto fue un buen título.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Recomendado. No es brillante, pero sí muy disfrutable.

121343143.review:
Recently decided to try and play through this on my Steam Deck. This review is moreso about the Steam Deck experience.

This game was great to finally finish, as I've attempted multiple times before but never really got into it. Being on the Steam Deck made it easy to pick up and play quickly. The controls are mapped to a standard Xbox 360 style, which makes it pretty intuitive. However, this game does run odd for its age on the Steam Deck. One of the main issues was that PhysX is on by default, when I turned that off the serious frame drops went away, but would still occasionally have minor drops. With PhysX on, there were points the game dropped down to 18fps average, with actual 3fps lows. After turning it off, it occasionally would dip into the 40's, but otherwise held 60fps most of the time.

The game itself is a simple, mostly on the rails parkour style game. It's obviously not open world, but has the illusion that it's very large due to the landscape being mostly large buildings/rooftops. Decent fun to pick up and play through, but not much replayability value for me personally.

121257798.review:
Nowadays it's hard to find information on it online, but there was this brief time were EA undertook an experiment: they made a few smaller scale games that were allowed to take more creative risks. Dead Space was one of those. Mirror's Edge the other. Sadly EA wasn't interested in continuing this program any further.

Anyway… Mirror's Edge a short and sweet game that holds up great today. The art direction is stunningly beautiful. The only thing the game could benefit in terms of graphics are maybe some higher resolution textures in some places.

The story is kinda boilerplate. It uses elements from film noir (getting framed for a crime you didn't commit, cutthroat politicians and businessmen, etc.) and a bit of sci-fi. The sci-fi part isn't really fleshed out that well. I don't think it would have taken that much to inject a little more environmental storytelling into the levels. Same goes for the runners themselves. I would have loved it if the game started out with you doing some normal runner jobs before the story really kicked off. But oh well, we didn't really get that.

And yet this game is special to me. I think it comes down to how incredibly stylish the game is in how it combines fluent gameplay, beautiful art direction and the amazing soundtrack by Swedish electronic minimal music genius Solar Fields.

121252229.review: Has some issues on newer hardware, as do many other games of the time, but nothing that can’t be fixed. The gameplay is smooth and holds up very well. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for the visuals. They're not [i]horrible[/i], but the high-contrast lighting scheme is jarring and the textures lack detail. Playing around with ReShade for a bit can make the experience much more enjoyable, but there’s not much you can do about blown out whites. If you’ve never played this game before, I’d highly recommend picking it up.

120804557.review:
5/10 good for people who like those "mastery 1-hit-death" games like Katana Zero, Hotline Miami, and Celeste (haha).  
Because of how punishing the platforming and combat is and how the game encourages complete mastery of the levels, repeat playthroughs are very encouraged while 1st playthroughs look like you running into bullets, walls, and to the pavement below.  It also instantly respawns you to run and die again in the same way just like those games listed above.  I hate that but some people like it because of how it gets you back into the action, but in my experience, it just promotes impatience and the successful run feeling like luck more than skill.
It's mid.  It's a shame that the story is lame and the combat was not fleshed out at all.  Lamest of all is how you have to use an exploit to get to full speed to make alot of the jumps (sidestep full dash camera swoop).
However, besides that, it's a fun hardcore parkour game.

120073152.review:
Years after playing this game for the first time on a PS3, I tried this while using EA play's subscription service and thankfully it aged quite well even if it's a 10+ year old game.
I believe the best aspect of the game is the level design. The lightning and the way colors reflect truly looks amazing, especially given this came out in 2008. Sprinting through a dark building then bashing a door open to get blinded by the sun feels oddly satisfying. 
Parkour feels great [b]when it works[/b]. Sometimes Faith the protagonist would do something you clearly didn't intend but it's a minor issue in the grand scheme of things given how forgiving the checkpoints are. 
The story is somewhat serviceable albeit a bit weak. You play as Faith who has to save her sister that got set up by unknown forces. It's possible to finish the story in the span of 4 to 5 hours, which leads to a small amount of time for character development but the strong score really boosts those special moments in the story and elevates it. 
It's definitely worth trying, as one of the few unique non shooters made by DICE, given no shortage of love from the devs.

120030346.review:
This is the first game that I have ever played that I cannot personally recommend... my streak was good while it lasted.

While Mirror's Edge has an amazing concept for a game and has really great, stylized visuals, there are a few key aspects of this game that prohibit me from recommending this game in good conscience. 

Firstly, during my play through I noticed that if I would die at certain points I would be teleported further ahead into the level, missing dialogue and context for the current scene. 

I also had issues with the controls. At times they felt unresponsive and they definitely felt clunky on a keyboard. There is the possibility that this game handles much better on a controller, but buying it on the PC really leaves no room for this sort of lackluster controlling on the keyboard.

Finally I would like to note the awful gun-play. While I understand that part of the idea was to discourage gun usage on enemies, there were times where I had to set down the game because the guns just did not work like they should. At certain distances your characters bullets WILL NOT hit an enemy regardless of where you aim while the enemies have immaculate aim and damage. There was a point in the mall level where I had to descend a full flight of stairs with a ton of enemies more than ten times just to complete the level.

To conclude, while this game had a ton of potential, I was left disappointed at the lackluster controls, skipping saves, and atrocious gun-play.

119863338.review: I have mixed thoughts on Mirror's Edge. Running around and doing parkour feels great, mostly: Faith has a nice sense of momentum, you can wall run and jump, and when you know what to do and where to go the game feels really great to play. Unfortunately, the combat in this game is atrocious and ranges from mildly annoying to downright frustrating. There were also a few instances where Faith would fail to grab a ledge or pipe, resulting in me plummeting to my death, but thankfully there's plenty of checkpoints that help with the frustration. This is also a pretty short game; my playthrough only took me about 4 hours (I don't know how I didn't beat this game as a teenager when Steam says I put 25 hours into it), and I wouldn't be surprised if a decent chunk of that time was me retrying sections after dying to something stupid. I don't hate Mirror's Edge but I don't really know if I like it either. I guess I like it more than I dislike it.

119301663.review:
Okay. To be entirely fair to this game, it's 13 years old... but that doesn't excuse the absolute lack of polish when it comes to *all* of its mechanics.

To begin, the most core part of the game is parkour... Unfortunately, it's non-fluid, unintuitive, and clunky. For a 2009 game it may have been great, but for 19.99 today? Utter shitshow. A game's mechanics should be reliable, predictable, and should be working well with the gameplay. The parkour is anything but reliable. For a game that's all about fluidity, you seem to be hindered by a light breeze. Turning is a shitshow of slowing you down, snagging corners make you come to a dead stop, and jumping toward a ledge is a complete cointoss of whether you'll land it, have to hope Faith grabs the ledge, or just plunging to your death because the game decided to say "No, you didn't grab the ledge this time". And yes, even when spamming spacebar, it is completely random whether or not it works. Springboards are another thing that only works when it wants to, and god forbid you disarm someone near one; It may trap you in the actual springboard.

The combat is... shit. Makes Skyrim look genious. Right-clicking when the gun turns red is a mechanic that only works when it feels like working. You can have timing down to a fucking tee, using slow-motion and everything, and still miss a disarm because the game just didn't feel like it at that moment. Which, in most cases, gets you killed and you need to go back to the last checkpoint...

The "Find your way" mechanic, where you press Left-Alt works so-so. It's a great idea, until implemented in a game where you're supposed to be running most of the time; Never press it near edges of rooftops, it WILL turn you into an involuntary skydiver. There's also the problem with it turning you to look straight into a wall, giving about as much information as a blank piece of paper.

It may have been a mistake to play Catalyst before this one, but I probably wouldn't have played Catalyst at all if I had done them in order; this game is just so off-putting when it comes to gameplay. At least the story is good.


*I actually have to edit this, because I got a bit further in the story, and somehow, everything has changed*

Not for the better, mind you. It's 10 times worse. The combat system is as wonky as ever, making the later parts of the game borderline unplayable. The parkour is as unreliable as an old Saab 900, to the point where you're actively looking for a way to get to the next checkpoint without having to press spacebar. And best of all; The little guidance that you did get from pressing Left-Alt only works if Left-Alt decides to work... but the devs decided that it needs to shut off at times. I'm actually impressed that I, not to mention my voice, has made it this far.

It gets even better, though. This entire game is rendered non-canon in Catalyst, as Faith thought Kate had been killed during the November Riots, and Kate thought that Faith had abandoned her. Wait no, that's Cat. Right, this entire game never happened... So I suffered through this for nothing, story-wise. Great.

Somewhat underwhelming! While the core gameplay loop is fun when you're on the rooftops, the game decides to make the levels more cramped as it progresses, making the freerunning aspect not as fun. While the aesthetic is indeed beautiful (especially for 2009), it is under-utilized as all the coolest set pieces are shown at the very start of the game. The story is incredibly basic and the cutscenes, while understandable due to budget, kinda bring it down. Personally, I think the running mechanics are wonky even when you're doing good and I felt like the flow was broken one too many times. There are a bunch of weird technical issues that you may encounter on modern systems, my least favourite being the credits song playing double (?) which is a damn shame, since it's one of the best things in this game. 

All in all, definitely had potential, shame that wasn't realised with the sequel!

118711833.review:
this game sat in my library after i bought it on sale for super cheap, and I'm so glad that I actually bothered to play it

it took me 10 minutes to love this game, the art style and gameplay are really good and the story is decent enough to carry you through it all

the graphics are really impressive for a game from 2008, in large part due to the really sexy baked in lighting that this game has (this also means it runs really well on modern hardware)

my only complaints are: 
-PhysX is a pain in the ass sometimes - to make it work properly I had to replace old files in the game's directory with new ones from the main physx directory (under the nvidia corporation folder), which was up-to-date
-combat is janky
-it's too short  - the game makes you want to see more of the city and experience more of the story behind it, but the short runtime doesn't allow for that (from what i understand the game's development was somewhat constrained)

I recommend you play this before catalyst (which is a reboot, not a sequel btw) but that doesn't mean either game is better - they're both unique and good in their own rights so play both of them (although myself I prefer this game because of its contemporary style compared with catalyst's cyberpunk setting)

TL:DR wait for a sale; this game is 100% worth the peanuts you can sometimes end up paying for it and if you don't like it, it won't end up costing you too much

118531471.review:
Mixed feelings. 

This game's pretty. Using a bright, sleek city and red/blue design language allowed the game to age gracefully. The movement is brilliant in idea, but I'm not convinced it's actually good, and that's the main gameplay. I've played 2 hours. The controls are weird still. They're OK though. What's less OK is the frequency I execute the controls properly but the game's auto-contextual elements don't work: I jump atop a zipline instead of jumping onto it to ... zipline. I climb a wall, hoping to hold the top and not jump over, but my character auto pulls herself up and throws herself to her death. Every AC game ever has done better on this front with similar or better movement. Between this, the game being so on-rails, the controls and the game's direction hints being so bad, it's in a weird spot for me. It has a lot going for it, but it's genuinely a bit frustrating. Oh, it also just crashes constantly. For example, every single time I alt-tab, it crashes. 

Overall, feels frustratingly close to being great. but for now, it's just good enough to beat for the $5 I got it for. I'm sure it'll be more fun as I get used to its idiosyncrasies, but there's a lot of them, and I suspect they'll annoy me for the better half of my short playthrough.

118134034.review:
[h1] TLDR: One of my favorite game ever. Its graphics and art-style are timeless. It's short and we never got the DLC for the Steam version but it is unique. The combat is wonky to the point where you're better off not engaging with it - but once you nail down the controls and feel of the game, you'll get into "the zone". Where the game wants you to be: always on the run. Always on the Edge. [/h1] 

I still remember the very first trailer. Being a big fan of parkour, I was immediately hooked, kept tabs on the game’s release and eventually, a demo came out on Xbox Live. 

Although extremely short, I played that demo to death. The movement felt amazing. The graphics and the art style were something else for 2008, even though it runs on UE3 which was known for its “grey and brown” aesthetic because of Gears of War. It still looks great today thanks to its immaculate visual design and its (at the time) unique baked Global Illumination solution. Every frame is screenshot material.

So I bought the game day one on 360 and had a blast… For about three hours. It’s that short. But Mirror’s Edge is all about running, thinking fast, finding a better path each time. So I kept playing, clearing the few different game modes it offered, and did the same on the PC version later. 

Even though I basically played the same levels a thousand times over I never got bored. Simply put, I never found another game like Mirror’s Edge. Even its sequel is very different, although similar at a glance. For you see, Mirror’s Edge is more of a racing game where you control a human being rather than a FPS or platformer. It’s more akin to SEUM or time trials in DiRT Rally than say Dying Light. 
It’s one of those games that puts you into “the zone” as they call it. You’ll feel like a speedrunner – except that’s just how the game is meant to be played.

The combat kinda sucks, to the point where it’s better to just ignore it as much as you can. Some sections of the game will somewhat force you to fight although it is possible to beat the game without killing anyone. 

The story is nothing to write home about. It’s there, it moves you from one level to the other without getting in the way so I guess it’s fine. The OST is absolutely amazing, composed by Solar Fields. A master of his craft which is ambient stuff. 

Now there is one notable downside with the Steam version: we never got the DLC, which is simply amazing. It’s Mirror’s Edge at its best. However, the PC version is moddable and it’s possible to play them that way now.

So, should you get Mirror’s Edge? Absolutely. Why? Because if you’ve never played it, you never played anything like it. And if you already played it – then you know you can clear that section you always had trouble with but faster. With a better flow. Without missing a single beat. Improving your time. So get to it.

Title: "Mirrors Edge: An Artistic Masterpiece of Movement and Emotion" [/b]

Introduction

Mirrors Edge is a revelation—a game that transcends mere entertainment to become an immersive, breathtaking, and life-changing experience. My passion for this game runs so deep that it inspired me to embark on my very own personal successor project, long before Catalyst even existed, during my college days in Games Design and Development. It's my pride and joy, all thanks to this game that continues to hold a special place in my heart.

The Enchanting Protagonist

At the heart of this masterpiece is Faith, a captivating and wonderfully developed protagonist. Her story, her convictions, the people she fights for, and her remarkable character arc are nothing short of exceptional. The culmination of her journey in the game's ending ranks among the finest moments in gaming history—beautiful, badass, and poetic in equal measure.

A Feast for the Senses

Mirrors Edge is an absolute feast for the senses. Its striking aesthetic, visionary visual design, and unique art style create a world that's as much a work of art as it is a game. The soundtrack is equally mesmerizing, introducing me to a treasure trove of emotionally charged music that still resonates with me to this day.

Parkour Prowess and Pulse-Pounding Action

The core of the game's brilliance lies in its parkour mechanics. The fluidity and grace of Faith's movements are nothing short of exhilarating. It's an experience that makes you feel like a true parkour/free-running virtuoso, effortlessly navigating the cityscape in ways that redefine the boundaries of what's possible in gaming. The game's action is relentless and intense, keeping you on your toes as you weave through the urban jungle.

Pros and Cons

Pros:
Unparalleled visual design and art style that create a captivating, immersive world.
A gripping story with a protagonist, Faith, who stands as one of the most compelling characters in gaming.
An emotionally resonant soundtrack that enhances the overall experience.
Parkour mechanics that make you feel like a true free-running maestro.
A sense of constant fluidity and intensity in the gameplay.

Cons:

While the parkour mechanics are sublime, they may take some time to master for newcomers.

Conclusion - An Artistic Marvel

In conclusion, Mirrors Edge isn't just a game; it's an artistic marvel, a breathtaking masterpiece that has the power to change lives. It's a game that's both fun and profoundly moving, an embodiment of pure artistic expression in the world of gaming. I cannot recommend it enough—it's a privilege and an honor to have experienced this gem in the world of interactive storytelling.

Back when this game was new and I was a fourteen-year-old kid, my friend gave me a copy of it.

Boy, did I suck.

I got stuck right at the training (my reaction speed just wasn't high enough for the space-Q-space combo), skipped it, but it didn't help, cause then I couldn't get past the first couple of cops.

Time passed, I've met Mass Effect that somewhat taught me how to shoot and got me into gaming, and somewhere down the road I've decided to give Mirror's Edge another try.

Turns out it's a whole lot of fun when you don't suck anymore. I like Faith, all the running, the possibility to wrestle a firearm from a cop and promptly show the rest of them they've made a massive mistake (why did you take that from me, Catalyst?), the beautiful city, all the colourwork, everything. Too bad I didn't take even nearly enough screenshots, cause most of the time I was busy hauling my ass.

Overall, great game, fond memories.

117972625.review:
Hop over this, slide under that, maybe don’t grab that electric fence again and definitely look before you leap because faith alone won’t be enough to survive this Matrix styled rooftop romp to rescue your sister before she is taken downtown for a crime she didn’t commit. Smash through windows, crawl through vents and disarm enemies along the way on Faith’s search for the truth. Seeing red is quite literal in this case in fact you are actually looking for it as it lights your path. Keep your allies close while you race to discover what revealing secrets lie at the top of the shard. 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Mirror’s Edge is a different kind of game from the style EA usually puts out. You play as Faith who is able to wall run and hop or slide her way through the city as a runner to transport things discreetly. She is trying to solve a crime that her sister has been framed for and she is racing against time itself to save her. 

The game itself feels a lot like a first person Enter the Matrix game minus most of the fighting. As a runner Faith primarily uses hand to hand combat and she can use guns if she disarms an enemy but the majority of the game is focused on speedrunning and it is usually in your best interests to avoid fighting unless you really have to. On consoles there was even a trophy for finishing the game without using any weapons.

Playing through the game in first person view definitely makes it rather interesting. You can look around for objects in red to help guide you to where you need to go but the game can also be incredibly picky, if you don’t do it in exactly the way it wants you to do it you will miss and have to keep repeating it until you figure out the way that they expect you to do it. Luckily the game is rather forgiving and if you miss a jump you won’t have to retrace your steps too far.

It is a very interesting game with a beautiful artistic style. The game isn’t all that long, but it does have a variety of different levels ranging from rooftops to underground sewers and unfinished construction sites to explore. Some of the later levels can be challenging because the enemies are heavily armored with machine guns and Faith dies in a couple of hits. The part with the server room on the final level was particularly frustrating. On the harder difficulty they don’t give you any help at all. You basically have to figure out how to navigate it by yourself without the red hints but if you have already played the game before then this shouldn’t be too complicated as you already will be familiar with how the gameplay works. 

This was one of the first games to showcase PhysX technology which was designed with a separate card dedicated to just physics in mind. Since then Nvidia integrated the technology into basically every geforce card and now you can run it without needing any additional hardware. I’ll admit it adds rather neat effects (like flapping tarpaulins in the wind as you are running on scaffolding or glass shards that shatter when you break a window). It had a big hit on performance with video cards when it was released (7800/8800 GTX) era but now a modern gpu should have no problems with it. The differences are rather subtle but it is pretty cool when it’s enabled it adds more realistic effects to certain things.

Overall I had a fun time with this game and once you have understood how the parkour style works it can be pretty rewarding as you focus more on the flow and learning how to keep the momentum going. It is a rather unique kind of experience. It's hard to compare this to other games as I don’t really know what to compare it to. There is a sequel to this that was built with the newer Frostbite engine and is similar but much prettier, it’s called Mirror’s Edge Catalyst. I do recommend this if you are looking for a game that is different from the usual RPG or FPS shooters and is more about fast thinking and intuition then this definitely might be of interest.

117830971.review:
First and foremost, I adore the vibe of Mirror’s Edge. Its ultra-vibrant environments and wind-kissed sound design is a real treat to the senses. Along with the iconic movement options of a seasoned parkour expert, Mirror’s Edge makes for a cozy seat in the driver’s side of a daredevil’s car.

As for the story, it wasn’t bad, just very predictable. If nothing else it at least justifies Faith’s running around with a believable reason. The only area of significant complaint is how finicky the game can be at times. For instance there were a few times where the objective marker didn’t work and I ended up at a dead end for a brief period, or times where enemies were a bit too obnoxious in their placement. In spite of that, I can’t come down on the game too hard. More than just an exhilarating parkour game, Mirror’s Edge is a cathartic breath of fresh air with its techno beats and rich colors. The kind of game that’s easy to lose yourself in every few years.

I want to like this game, It has a cool concept but the game play experience is just slow and beyond frustrating.

117548562.review:
I don't know if it's worth $20, but for the $5 I spent I think it just barely squeezes by with a recommendation. There are a lot of annoyances, but overall I think it's an important part of gaming history that most people should experience.

[h1] The Good! [/h1]
Let's start out with the good. For one, the movement itself feels great. Getting a long string of successful jumps together feels awesome. The sense of momentum is almost perfect, and the feeling of presence in the game world is some of the best that I've experienced in any 1st person game. The great sound design, viewable 1st person body, and good animations help both of these points become a reality. 

Secondly, the art direction and world design is truly timeless. The semi-realistic, slightly stylized city and the clean, solid, bright colors make for a game that still looks great 13 years later. You can see the low-ish polygon count if you stop and look around, but the game is so fast that you usually don't have time to. 

The animated 2D cutscenes are also really fun to watch and are so much more interesting than if they were boring 3D in-engine cutscenes like most other games. The voice-acting is also great all around.

Lastly, Faith is just a badass character. She's so fuckin' cool and really fun to play as. You really feel like a superhero playing as her, and her backstory and motivations round out the character perfectly.

[h1] The Bad! [/h1]
That being said, there are a LOT of annoyances that keep this game from being a masterpiece. Firstly, the combat feels extremely half-baked and clunky. It can feel cool when you are able to disarm an enemy and use his weapon to clear a rooftop of baddies, but most of the time that doesn't happen. Most of the time you awkwardly flop around and whiff your attacks before being completely rekt. The best parts of the game are when they leave you alone and just let you jump around by yourself for a while.

One small thing I didn't like is how abrupt the ending is. There isn't a single line of dialogue after the last short gameplay section, it just suddenly rolls to credits. I'm not saying it needed to be super complex, but having nothing at all just feels kinda rushed.

Lastly, the game is way too easy in general with how frequent the checkpoints are. It almost feels like playing an old arcade game with unlimited quarters. You'll die a shit-ton, but you always respawn like 10 feet from where you died so you can just kinda mindlessly brute-force your way through most of it.

Also, the game breaks when alt-tabing, so don't do it.

[h1] Overall [/h1]
Overall it's at LEAST a solid 8.5/10 experience. I'd recommend it to anyone at $5, but maybe hold off on a full-price purchase unless you plan on playing it several times, because there just isn't that much content.

116949802.review:
After finally giving Mirror's Edge a playthrough, I would highly recommend this game to anyone that's a fan of parkour or FPS games. While it can be challenging to get the controls down, the game is smooth with a unique and very pleasing art style. There are some draw backs in my opinion, like a short story and rudimentary gunplay, it more than makes up for with extra content (remember when that was a thing?), and time challenges; with those negatives even adding to the charm of the experience, in my opinion. Sadly though, EA being EA, the asking price is just shy of $30 CAD - nearly [i]half[/i] of the original asking price back in [b]2008[/b]. While you can pick this game up for around $5 on sale (although I can't say the same with all their other games), this is just plainly unacceptable, and hurts the series overall as it drives potential fans away - ever more shrinking the community, and lessening the probability that this game will get future support, or more games in the franchise. If you do end up grabbing this game, please do so on sale! We don't need to be encouraging this behaviour. 

Honestly, I miss the days when large studio's weren't afraid to take a risk and release a game with a new formula or idea like this game, instead of the same old microtransaction filled stuff we get nowadays. Don't get me wrong, with publishers like EA it's going to be profit over the consumer - it always has been - but maybe if there were more new games like Mirror's Edge coming out today, we'd over look the old DLC way of doing things. Just a thought though...

Do I seriously need to add anything? I mean you looking for a parkour game? This was the game, this is the game and probably will remain the best as a classic forever. So what are you even waiting for?

Here are a few things I noticed about the game that made me enjoy it:

The challenges: For those of us who like to play at the hardest difficulty, this is not that hard of a game but it forces you to escape rather than fight if you do not master combat skills as much. The fact that the red door guides you is nice but I think it can be more challenging to simply remove it on the hardest difficulty. Apart from this, there is races and you may always want to re-approach the game in a different way.

The level design: I appreciate the simplicity on the game and really liked the modernity which the game brings in terms of the looks. Again it isn't as diverse as the second one but it is still up to date. I like the simplicity of it, I felt like I was outdoor on a sunny day chilling on the rooftops and then when the chases kick in, you really are motivated to search for the best escape and the game does a good job as to pointing you to where you need to go.

Worth buying in today's time?: Well today as i'm writing this we are in 2022 and the game was made in 2009 and I definitely would go back to it even in the future. In a sense this game is still the best parkour game you can find at the moment.

115200489.review:
[b] Story [/b]
Well, like an old-fashioned action film, you can easily imagine what will happen next. And there is no options, no variations, there is just a single plot. If you try to change the flow of the story somehow, the system force it back. Plus, if you don't finish the story mode, you can't play other mode.

[b] Combat [/b]
They prepared several chances of combat in the story mode, and  it was a, well, SH!T.
The enemies have longer reach than you, faster than you, can detect you wherever you are, and get knock back or groggy irregularly.
And then you, the protagonist, seems couldn't got much talent. You can punch maximum 3 times at single attack. But if you start the flow of the punch combination, you can not do anything, such as moving, jumping, counterattack, etc., until you finished 3rd blow of the punch. Oh, Yes, counterattack. You can take over the enemies gun by the counterattack, and at the same time, you can knock them out too. And it has cool action.  But it doesn't mean you are invulnerable during counterattack. And usually, you fight with several enemies at same time.
Well, there are many great things about combat, like a camera view fixing bug, stupid AI, etc., just play and feel it. It will be awesome.

[b] Conclusion [/b]
I was excited to play this game. Steam store reviews were VERY POSITIVE, many people praised this game, PV was looked good. Then, what else? And, yes, <Mirror's Edge> is cool PARKOUR game. If my friend ask me about this game, I will answer "This is cool game. You must play this." And I will be happy to waiting his reaction.

115055184.review:
I have played about 400 hours of Mirror's Edge on an Xbox 360 and another 100 hours on Xbox One's backwards compatibility, having set some time trial highscores in the past. Mirror's Edge is easily one of my favorite games of all time, and PC is easily the go-to best place to experience the game.

This is easily a title that could be considered a "comfort game". Its short length, combined with gameplay that is easy to learn, hard to master and extremely rewarding makes this a great experience to pick up on and off whenever. The modding community has also been growing a lot over the past few years, with many custom maps and even a multiplayer mode being developed. The replay value is huge. Of course, the game has its flaws such as the clunky combat and often poor hitboxes on pipes and such, however, it's still a very positive experience.

The game is worth $20, but it frequently goes on sale as low as 90% off. Grab it and enjoy the charming unique style of the game. Not even its reboot-sequel Catalyst managed to be as special as this gem.

114912988.review:
Long time ago, when a piracy was at its best and I was a dumb kid, I downloaded Mirror's Edge. It was 2010 and it was the first game I played on my previous computer. I still remember the feeling. Oh nostalgia.

Now, when I am a grown up with my own money I just had to buy the game properly.
After all these years the game does not feel old at all. There are some bugs here and there, personally I found the main protagonist looking weird, but the joy of playing is still the same.

Level design is uncommonly good. There are only few places that I stucked for a longer while, but in general, despite the feeling of freedom, it leads a player smoothly through vast areas.
When it comes to graphic, it is still beautiful even though the game is already 13 years old! I know it is mostly because the graphic is actually very simple, but textures and colors do the work even after all these years.
Music is pretty cool and immersive too.

What I don't like about the game is the story and what I truly hate is cartoony cutscenes animation. They are just ugly.

Mirror's Edge was an innovative game when it was released and it is still a superb game to play.
I strongly recommend it.

114899574.review: Fun platformer, that was a product of it's time.

114885517.review:
I don't think i was ever more dissapointed in playing a game in my life.
This is one of those games i didn't really want to hate [or thought id hate] but i ended up really disliking it but i feel i do have reasons justified here, game just is clunky.
The visuals are the strong part [except the character models] its simplistic, bright, colorful, and even darker levels look pleasing, tho i do feel sometimes game is too bright and then too dark in those spots but nothing too bad.
Great now i can talk bad about this game.
Its a platformer, runner, where i feel like i want to go outside and do this shit because i feel like ill do better. Firstly the game is suprisngly slow, its about building momentum but even when you run for a bit and build up speed its just slow, i did expect to run faster than an average game lets you but this feels slower than an average game lets you. Your move set for free running is also suprisngly weak, there is crouching for sliding and letting go of objects and jumping for clinging up to them or wall jumping. Thats pretty much it but using those is off at times. Certain actions youll do using those is climbing pipes, or clinging onto some platforms and troughout the game you just miss the things. Id jump on pipes in a way and id just drop next to them and next time i respawn id slide down them. Same with platforms there is 1 spot where i actually caught on a platform below another so i couldn't climb up, and another where i climbed up a Vent's top part [got a screenshot of that] There is absolutely no, how to say it, adjustment from the game? Like if you aren't on point you are going to fall.
Think of another game, here ill drop an extremely random one, GTA, hate me all you want but jumping from building to building in San Andreas is absolutely fine, and you can do some mad clinging on buildings, hell CJ will cathc something mid jump if there is something where as at times in Mirrors Edge id have to repoisition myself and then hope id catch the thing im looking at.
Fall damage is completely random, there is a roll mechanic where you nulify it but the falls that require it don't make sense. I had taken damage in vents and some shorter heigts and then id fall just fine on certain higher stuff i just ended up doing the roll just to make sure nothing happened.
Combat is unimpressive. Hand to hand you have like 4 moves, punch, disarm, dropkick and lowkick and in all honestly its too basic. There isn't even a block so you are there just mashing until you kill something, there is a dodge tho, at least i think its a dodge. There isn't any interesting combat combo, or some cool move you can pull off like on load screens. Now i didn't expect something like Oni or Yakuza but i sure didn't expect this little of it. Shooting which i commonly heard is the worst part of the game is honestly kinda fun, there is no weight to it and sounds aren't too great either but suddenly coming up and taking an enemy's gun and then moving others is just fun.
And this is best part of Mirrors Edge, starting something and then it developing it, doing multiple platforming jumps in a row, chaining enemies and yknow, cool stuff. But you don't do that.
There are quite a few scenarios down the line that just seem poorly thought out. Shooting sections require you to pick of 1 enemy with a gun and then from there go to the rest but there is 2 sections i feel like you are put in an ass position where you will die over and over. To quickly talk about disarms, cool mechanic, seems absolutely broken for 1 of the guns, and 2 particular sections i talk about have 2 enemies in your sights with those guns, very very very not fun.
There is a platforming bit on a train where timing of your jump is very scuffed imo i don't think i even deserved to pass it once i did. An elevator one where i straight up gave up trying to catch a wire mid air after a while. Aperently high framerates mess with physics but i checked its aperently fine on 60 and thats what i played on.
Story is just dumb, partially has to do with the game being like 4 to 5 hours at most which i don't know what was the price of this game at release but that is low, its especelly obvious when the game just goes from 1 to 100 to like 50 to whatever else it wants.
And really this game is doing what it wants, the story does what it wants, the platforming works when it wants and the shooting sections are fair when they want to be.
There are just better games for hand to hand combat, platforming, shooting, story and while at times Mirror's edge is a nice combination it doesn't help it from the fact that in reality all those things are poor.

114748540.review:
I really, really like the idea of this game - but I think the execution falls flat in many places. Combat is extremely punishing, the controls can be finicky, and the "puzzle" aspect of figuring out where to go sometimes breaks the flow and turns the game into "I-Spy", which just doesn't seem to add a lot of value in the context of the rest of the games appealing aspects (flowing from obstacle to obstacle and figuring out efficient, stylish routes).

Oftentimes, enemies are best dealt with by acquiring a weapon and treating the game like an FPS. Maybe I'm just bad, but most layouts seem really hard to approach enemies, especially when they cover each other or group up due to the AI's movement strategies.
